loans.name: Bold

texts.en:
Bold, 27, is married and lives with his wife and two-year-old son in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. He works as a computer program developer. He now earns money from a computer program he recently developed called Message Messy by cooperating with TV channels. It is a program that TV channels can use to communicate with the public through mobile texting. People can send texts while the channel is on and participate in TV games or order their favorite music. 

Now he is working on other programs and his previous work helps him to earn an income that supports his family. He wants to improve his developing skills and expand his business operation. He is a hard-working, sociable and dedicated person who wants to operate his own TV channel in the future. Bold is requesting a loan of 3,000,000 MNT to prepare new broadcast in C1 TV.

loans.use: To prepare a  new broadcast

loans.name: Pich

texts.en:
Pich S. has been in the farming business for many years. She learned this skill from her grandparents back when she was single. Pich S. has two children; one is single and the other one is married. The two of them work at jobs and have a proper salary per month.

 Pich S. always cultivates rice crops, both in the rainy season and the dry season, and she has had great success growing her crops. Her husband currently is a bed seller in  Kompong Tom province, and the daily income which he can earn from his business is about $3.50 per day. In order to improve the business, Pich S.’s husband wants to buy more wood to make beds to sell. This is the reason why Pich S. is seeking a loan from Kiva through HKL.

loans.use: To purchase more wood to make beds to sell

loans.name: Cherilyn

texts.en:
Cherilyn is a married woman who lives in Carmen, Cebu. She earns her living by operating one business venture: vehicle repairs. Her husband William, who is 47 years old, works as a welder to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have four children who are between 3 and 24 years old. 

Cherilyn joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 4 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Cherilyn has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 14,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 12,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 5th loan, she is borrowing PHP 17,000, which she intends to use to buy materials for vehicle repairs  so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Cherilyn is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:

 In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase raw materials for the repairing of vehicles

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Horloo

texts.en:
Horloo, 37, is married and lives with her husband and two children in Uvurhangai province, Mongolia. Her husband is currently unemployed and her two children attend local secondary school. 

Horloo graduated from college as a designer and she started her sewing business after her graduation. She operates a sewing service at a local trading center. She makes various types of clothing including traditional and modern. She is popular in her area as she has been operating her business for about eight years and she has her regular customers. She is a reliable customer of our bank. 

Horloo says, " I am trying to expand my business in order to save for my children's future studies and open my own workshop where I could train my students." She is requesting a loan of 3,500,000 MNT to buy necessary materials for her sewing business.

loans.use: To buy necessary materials

loans.name: Lorena

texts.en:
Lorena T. is a married woman who lives in Brgy. Buluang, Compostela, Cebu . She earns her living by operating one business venture: a recycling (scrap)  business.  Her husband Henry T., who is 30 years old, works as a laborer to earn his living.  They have seven children who are 5 months to  10 years old. 

Lorena joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 6 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Lorena has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 8,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6,700,  uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 7th loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000, which she intends to use for additional capital for the scrap business so that she can generate a lot of money to save up for future home repairs and her childen's education.

 Lorena T. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: to fund operations as a scrap dealer

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en: Catherine is a 35-year-old married lady.  She is blessed with two children aged 2 and 3.  She sells second-hand clothes.  She also owns a salon which she was previously operating before she started selling clothes.  She hopes to start selling clothes wholesale in the future.  She is very grateful to Faulu Kenya for her previous loan because she was able to boost her business.  She has also been saving her money with Faulu Kenya.  She has requested a loan of 60,000 Kes to add to her used clothing inventory.

loans.use: To add stock of clothes

loans.name: Gunne

texts.en: Gunne is currently in the business of selling soft drinks, for example soda, water, etc. She is 25 years old and married to a policeman. Gunne has no children yet. She has taken out a loan to stock more soft drinks, for example sodas, water,etc. to sell. In the future, Gunne hopes to build a house to rent out with extra profits from her business.

loans.use: Stock more soft drinks, for example sodas, water, etc. to sell

loans.name: Rani's Group

texts.en:
Rani is 45 years old and comes from Arifwala which is a small city in Punjab, Pakistan, known for its dairy industry.  She lives there in the area of Muzafarabad in a 3-room brick house with her family. She came here 24 years ago. 

She is involved in selling clothing. She purchases clothes from the city of Lahore and sells to her community clients on order. She offers her clients a good variety of clothes at their doorsteps and makes good sales every month. Her husband’s name is M. M. and he sells used clothes in the bazaar. A person who can’t afford to buy new and costly clothes prefers shopping with him. 

Rani is the mother of three sons and two daughters. Her daughters work in private organizations while one of her son is enrolled in a local school and getting his education. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband, who will utilize the loan money in buying used clothes in bulk. This will help him offer more variety to his clients and make more sales. 

He has been operating his business for the past 21 years and Rani is hopeful that after the loan investment, his business will start bringing him better profit. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 5th loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained a good credit behavior and never missed any meeting.

loans.use: To buy used clothes to sell

loans.name: Leab

texts.en:
The woman in the photograph is Leab P., age 48, who lives in the province of Kompong Tom, which is the best territory for farming. She lives with her five children in her own house. Two of them work for a construction company, and they often contribute their profits to her to use for the family’s needs. 

Leab P. owns a big farm that she inherited from her grandmother. She plants a rice crop; that is her annual business. This is the harvest season, but she hasn't harvested her finished product yet. She would like to request a loan to hire a few domestic laborers to harvest her rice crop.

loans.use: To hire a few domestic laborers to harvest her rice crop.

loans.name: Eden

texts.en:
Eden is a married woman who lives in Puerto Princesa City, Palawan. She earns her living by operating three business ventures:  a vegetable garden, tricycle transport and a buying and selling of flowers business. Her husband, Reynaldo, who is 45 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have four children who are between 7 and 15 years old. 

Eden joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2003 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past twenty-four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Eden has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 12,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of approximately $239, raising the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 25th loan, she is borrowing 22,000 PHP, with which she intends to buy seeds for the vegetable garden so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Eden is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 	

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. 

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: to buy seeds for her vegetable garden

loans.name: Emalinda

texts.en:
Emalinda is a 47-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating two business ventures:  fish vending and a piggery business.  She lives in Puerto Princesa City, Palawan. 

Emalinda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2006 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past ten loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Emalinda has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 17,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of approximately $460, raising the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 11th loan, she is borrowing 25,000 PHP, with which she intends to buy fresh fish to resell so that she can continue to save up for the future expansion of her business. Emalinda is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. 

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking on the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more fresh fish to resell

loans.name: Orlando's Group

texts.en:
Orlando B. is from the village of Cabisera 5, Ilagan, Isabela. He is 48 years old. Orlando is the group leader of a three-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Orlando B.'s Group.

Orlando is married and has two adult-aged children. To make a living, he owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, planting and harvesting rice and corn for sale. He has been engaged in his business for over thirty-one years and earns approximately $117 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Orlando joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. 

Orlando is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This will be his 2nd loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise

loans.name: Jonalyn

texts.en:
Jonalyn is a 32-year-old single woman who supports her family by operating a motorcycle repair shop. She lives in Puerto Princesa City, Palawan. Jonalyn joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past eleven loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Jonalyn has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 25,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of approximately $812, thus raising the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 12th loan, she is borrowing 28,000 PHP, which she intends to use as additional working capital so that she can continue to save up for the expansion of her business. Jonalyn is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.  

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. 

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase raw materials for the shop

loans.name: Tsevelravjaa

texts.en:
Tsevelravjaa is 48 years old and married. She lives with her children in the Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. They live in a ger, Mongolian nomadic housing tent, and have been living in the same place for about ten years. 

Tsevelravjaa began her retail business by selling meat and meat products at a local market. In 2006, she started a clothing business at an outdoor stall. Now, she operates a kiosk at a trading center called Orgil which she opened in 2008. Tsevelravjaa purchases clothing for her business from China once or twice a month depending on her income. She is requesting a loan of 3,000,000 MNT to purchase more clothing for her business. 	

Tsevelravjaa is a reliable bank customer who has paid back several loans on time. She is a sociable and neat person who says, “I am trying hard to expand my business and increase my working capital in order to save for my daughter’s future studies. I also want to improve my profit to build a house and to operate my own store.”

loans.use: to purchase clothing

loans.name: Mark

texts.en:
Mark K. is 22 years old. He is single and supports his parents. For the past three years, he has been a hawker, selling foodstuffs, such as snacks and juices, along with second-hand clothes in Narok town. 

Mark learned about KADET from other men in a group already registered with KADET in Narok town. This will be his first loan and he is planning to buy more inventory to sell. Mark hopes to use the profit from his loan to build a permanent home. He is an industrious man who is determined to achieve his objectives. Mark's dream is to build rental houses and expand his business.

loans.use: to buy inventory

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen is 46 years old and married with four children. He owns pool tables for commercial use and also runs a retail shop. Stephen also earns extra income from his rental houses and is able to educate his children with the income from his businesses.

Stephen has requested a loan of 80,000 KES to buy a pool table. In the next five years, he hopes to own twenty more pool tables.

loans.use: to buy a pool table

loans.name: Sao

texts.en:
Sao N. was born in 1963. She is a married woman and a good mother who is blessed with four children who are single. Two of her children are employed as overseas workers. To earn a living, Sao N. cultivates rice with her husband. 

Sao N. needs people to help with her farming business. She is requesting a loan from Kiva to hire domestic laborers to work with her to harvest her rice crop.

loans.use: to hire harvest laborers

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en:
Juliana is a married woman who lives in Puerto Princesa City, Palawan. She earns her living by operating a general store. Her husband Francisco, who is 63 years old, works as a carpenter to earn his living and helps with his wife’s business activities. They have six children who are between 27 to 43 years old. Juliana joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 15 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Juliana has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. 

This time, for her sixteenth loan, Juliana is borrowing 15,000 PHP to buy product items for her store and to save for the future. Juliana is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through its alleviation program, NWTF is empowering women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: to purchase basic products for general store

loans.name: Predeswinda

texts.en:
Predeswinda is 25 years old and married. She lives in Puerto Princesa City, Palawan and supports her family by operating two businesses: a general store and an aqua-farming business. Predeswinda has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2010 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and aqua-farming businesses, Predeswinda is gradually making her family more economically stable and now earns an average monthly income of 20,000 PHP. 

Predeswinda is requesting a loan of 12,000 PHP to purchase inventory for her general store. This will be her second loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. She repaid her previous loan well within its term. Predeswinda aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through its alleviation program, NWTF is empowering women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: to purchase general store inventory

loans.name: Suan

texts.en: Sewing clothes is the main part of 46-year-old Suan S.’s daily routine. She provides this service to her neighbors and sews both traditional clothes and modern clothes at home. She runs her business very well and a lot of customers recognize the good service she provides. She is married to Srey Chantha, 44, a policeman, and they have two young children. This rice harvesting season, and Suan S. has applied for this loan to buy many sacks of rice to store. She will sell them later, when the price of rice rises to its highest level.

loans.use: To buy rice now, when the price is low, and sell it when prices are higher

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en: Isaac is a businessman who makes a living by running a green grocery. He also offers bicycle transportation services to people who trade goods in the local market. His wife helps him by running the grocery when he is busy transporting goods. His main goal is to open new outlets of his grocery store and hire people to run them. He is applying for this loan for 40,000 Kes, to buy pineapples, onions, melons and tomatoes to sell to customers in his store.

loans.use: To buy pineapples, onions, melons and tomatoes to sell to his customers

loans.name: Altangadas

texts.en: Altangadas, 35, is married and lives with his wife and 10-year-old daughter in Mongolia's Uvurhangai province. They live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. His daughter attends a local primary school, while he works at a taxi service he started in 2005. For the last two years, his wife has made a living selling cosmetics at a stall she rents in the local market. In addition to driving his taxi, Altangadas also helps his wife at her stall. As an experienced salesperson, his wife operates her cosmetic trading business successfully. They are planning to expand this business and build a winter house where they can live a more comfortable life. He is applying for a loan of 1,900,000 MNT to buy more cosmetics to sell in their stall.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetics to sell in a local market.

loans.name: Zamira's Group

texts.en:
Kyrgyz farmers have always made a living by raising poultry. Zamira N., 30, is a member of this four-person loan group who makes a living in this way. This business keeps her very busy caring for her animals, gathering fresh eggs and delivering them to market. She also sells her poultry, largely during New Years and in the spring, when prices are highest. To increase her income, she would like to expand into cattle-breeding, and she is applying for a loan to buy cattle to raise. 

Where Did This Loan Come From?
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and watch a video about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to buy cattle for breeding

loans.name: James

texts.en: James is 34 years old, married and has two children. For the last seven years, he has made a living by running a barber shop and a salon. He now has three employees, and supplements his income by selling hides and skins on the side. He hopes to expand his business into a full-service beauty parlor in the next five years. As a member of the Hanan group, which is affiliated with Faulu Kenya, he can easily access capital because people in his loan group pledge to guarantee each other's loans.  He also uses his group as a tool for saving money. He is applying for this loan for 40,000 Kes to buy a sink, sterilizing equipment and an electric shaver.

loans.use: To buy a sink, sterilizing equipment and a shaver

loans.name: Zinakan Orozalieva's Group

texts.en:
This group of entrepreneurs has four members. The group leader is Lira Astrakhanova, and members are Zinakan O., Abdilbek S., and Bolotbek S.. They are close friends and colleagues and are united by a common goal: they each would like to get a loan from Kiva for their cattle-breeding businesses. 

Zinakan O. is 35 and is the group treasurer. She is married with three children and her husband works in the security service of a local company. Just like her fellow group members, Zinakan breeds cattle. At this moment, she has only three head of cattle but she hopes, with help of Kiva, to increase that number. Six years ago, when she and her husband decided to start this business, Zinakan admits that she was nervous and uncertain. But she has gained valuable experience and now has her own strategy for business promotion. Her business earns her 4,000 KGS monthly, and the family has saved enough to purchase home electronics. In the future, Zinakan would like to make major repairs to her house and improve her family’s living conditions.

 
      --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – people (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Battumur

texts.en: Battumur is 54 years old and lives in the Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. All of her children are married and now she lives alone in a ger, a Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in her son’s backyard. In 2009, Battumur started a felt craft and production business making Mongonlian traditional boots after participating in training organized by World Vision, a non-governmental organization. Battumur makes boots and felt crafts that are ordered by World Vision. This provides an income source for her. Battumur is requesting a loan of 300,000 MNT to purchase felt to use in her business.

loans.use: to purchase felt

loans.name: Sein

texts.en: Mrs. Sein T. is a villager in Andoung Samretth village in Takeo province and she was born in 1967. She is a farmer who owns 2-hectare plot of land where they grow rice to sell to support their family. To improve rice production, Mrs. Sein T. is applying for a loan to buy rice seed, fertilizer, pesticide, and hire farming laborers so as to farm in the dry season. Her husband, Mr. T. Khiev is a duck breeder who is able to earn some money selling duck eggs to support his family. She is a mother of four children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory, while another one is a construction worker, and the others are students. Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy rice seed, fertilizer, pesticide, and hire farming laborers

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca is a married woman who lives in Puerto Princesa City, Palawan. She earns her living by operating three business ventures:   tricycle transport, sari-sari (general) store and piggery businesses. Her husband Eduardo, who is 48 years old, works as a truck driver to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have four children who are 10 to 23 years old and currently going to school. 

Rebecca joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2003 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 20 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Rebecca has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 18,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 12,300, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 21st loan, she is borrowing PHP 18,000, with which she intends to buy new tools and equipment for the three-wheeled vehicle so that she can continue to save up for the future and for the education of her children. Rebecca is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase new tools and equipment for their three-wheeled vehicle (tricycle)

loans.name: Keji

texts.en: Keji is currently in the business of selling goods like sodas, water, etc. She is 40 years old, married, with five children and all of them go to school. She took out a loan to stock more goods to sell, for example sodas, water, etc. Keji hopes to build a house to rent out in the future with extra profits from her business.

loans.use: Stock more goods to sell, for example sodas, water, etc.

loans.name: Mairam's Group

texts.en:
Every businessman aims to have a sustainable and flourishing activity that will be useful to him and to society. Introducing new food products at an affordable price is very important for a grocery store. This creditor Mairam does her best to provide good customer service and healthy products. 
 
Mairam A., 37, is the treasurer of this group. She’s a business lady who runs a small grocery store that she opened 4 years ago by her house. She doesn’t have any employees because she can manage all services herself. She works hard to provide for her family. Three of her children go to school and the youngest is 2 years old. Mairam says it’s a convenient business, because she can stay close to home and take care of her daughter. 

Mairam’s husband is a tractor driver in a local farm. She has to constantly invest 12 000 soms in the goods circulation of her shop. A monthly income of 5 000 soms helps her to keep business stability and a good economic welfare for her family.  Mairam hopes that Kiva’s loan will help her to furnish her shop with a wide assortment of goods and attract more customers. 

      --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase a variety of household products to sell

loans.name: Kennedy

texts.en: Kennedy is a member of Maridadi group registered under Faulu Kenya.  He does plumbing so as to earn his daily bread.  He has been in the business for seven years.  He was previously farming before he went into this business.  Kennedy is married and a father of three.  He works hard to provide for his family including educating his children.  He hopes to own a real estate in the future.  He needs 40,000 Kes to buy pipes and fittings.

loans.use: To buy pipes and fittings

loans.name: Paing

texts.en: Paing S. is 36 years old and has been selling Khmer noodles in her community for more than five years. She sells her noodles every morning, making an average of $4 per day to support her family's daily expenses. She is divorced and has two school-aged children. In order earn additional profit, Paing S. says that she intends to buy fish to make fish-paste to sell.

loans.use: To buy fish to make fish-paste to sell.

loans.name: Dolgorsuren

texts.en: Dolgorsuren is 31 years old and lives with her two children in Uvurhangai province, Mongolia. Her son attends a local secondary school. They live in their own ger (Mongolian nomadic housing tent). Dolgorsuren began her meat-trading business in 2000. She purchases meat and milk products from local individuals who bring their products from the countryside to sell in the city using her micro bus. She is hardworking and someone with initiative who wants to expand her business and increase her profit. Dolgorsuren's further wish is to give a better education to her children and build her own house. She is requesting a loan of of 1,500,000 MNT to purchase more meat for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more meat

loans.name: Mukadas' Group

texts.en:
Mukadas N., 62, is treasurer of this group. Twenty years ago she decided to turn what she did best — cooking —  into a business. She is a resident of a small town, Karabalta, where there are many small cafeterias selling national cuisine. National cuisine of Kyrgyzstan has a vast variety of hot dishes and desserts. The major part of hot dishes consists of meat and vegetables. There are small cafes, big restaurants, and street food offered in cities and towns throughout Kyrgyzstan.

Mukadas rents a small cafeteria in a center of the town and employs several people. Every day, especially during lunch times, she serves dozens of customers. She is married and has three grown sons, who also help her with managing the cafeteria’s expenses. Her oldest son has a permanent job as a lawyer in Russia, while her youngest son has a retail business in cell phones and accessories. Mukadas is applying for a loan to furnish the cafeteria and add some more dishes to her menu. She hopes to make more profit and improve her family’s living conditions. 

        --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society); Planet (keeping environmentally friendly); and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team — Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to furnish her cafeteria and expand its menu

loans.name: Azamat's Group

texts.en:
Azamat J. U., 19, is the youngest member of this group. He’s a resident of Karabalta and lives with his seventeen-year-old sister, who is financially dependent on him. Azamat is a part-time student at a local university, and when he’s free from studies, he works in a local market selling vegetables. He has done this for two years and says that it gets frustrating sometimes as he faces challenges such as perishable products, weather conditions and inflation. He believes that the secret of success in retail is high quality, so he tries to deliver wholesale goods on time and at a more affordable price than his competitors. 

The idea for the business came from Azamat’s mother, who helped him start it by buying three sacks of potatoes. Since then Azamat has achieved good results. He’s earned enough to pay his university tuition and has applied for a loan from Kiva, because he would like to purchase a small shop. Working in an open air market makes it more difficult for him to deliver his services, especially in cold winter conditions. Teenage labor has increased recently in Kyrgyzstan. The causes are few opportunities to get a college education and the availability of low-paid jobs.

         --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society); Planet (keeping environmentally friendly); and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team — Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase a small kiosk

loans.name: Mahmoud

texts.en: Mahmoud is a 44 year-old married man, father of four kids, who is working as an insurance broker for 17 years. He opened his own brokering office 6 years ago,in order to make a good start to a direct insurance provider, then to the dream insurance company.  Mahmoud is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua, for the third time, in order to pay for the necessary maintenance to his office. Mahmoud is a good-standing borrower whose previous loans helped in improving his business as well as his social situation. Mahmoud is well known in the region and most of his clients recommend dealing with him. He hopes to open his own insurance company in the future and has his children work with him to expand his business.

loans.use: To do necessary maintenance to his office

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en: Stephen, 41 years old, married and blessed with a three-year-old child, sells radios, watches, belts and calculators so as to earn a living.  Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has become more self-reliant because his business has grown.  Paul hopes to expand his business into wholesale in the future, and he is now requesting 30,000 Kes to buy radios, watches, torches and belts.

loans.use: To buy radios, watches, torches and belts

loans.name: Aizada's Group

texts.en:
Women comprise a significant share of Kyrgyzstan’s labor force, most of them involved in trade, a very important part of Kyrgyzstan’s activities.

Aizada S. K., the 34-year-old treasurer of this group, is married and has two young sons. Her husband works in transportation services, while she has been involved in the retail of women's apparel in a local market for eight years. When he’s free from work, her husband tries to substitute for her at work so that she can spend more time at home with the children.

Starting this business with a loan of 20,000 from a local bank, Aizada's good management enabled her to quickly repay the loan. She currently earns a monthly income of 7,800 soms and has thus far been able to purchase nice furniture for their house.

With the loan she is requesting from Kiva, Aizada plans to purchase more goods and diversify her assortment. The anticipated profit will be spent on purchasing a permanent place for retail in the market and an automobile.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes

loans.name: Lanh

texts.en:
Lanh S., 27 years old, owns a small wooden house and a grocery shop where she sells many items, including cooking ingredients, sweets, soft drinks, and other goods to passers-by and her neighbors. She has been operating this enterprise for a long time and earns an average of $1.25 a day. To ensure the entire family's financial stability, her husband works as a firewood seller. This couple has two children, both of whom are attending school. 

In order to sustain other expenses of the whole family, Lanh S. is taking out her loan to buy piglets to raise for sale during the period when pork is commanding the highest price. With the remaining funds, she will buy a pot for distilling liquor.

loans.use: To buy piglets to raise for sale and a pot for distilling liquor.

loans.name: Dame

texts.fr: Monsieur Dame K. est un boutiquier qui gère une alimentation générale à Mbour au quartier Médine Extension il exerce ce métier depuis prés de 4 ans. Il est célibataire et soutien de famille. Médine étant un quartier enclavé monsieur K. a voulu investir dans le secteur alimentaire. Ainsi, il vient solliciter ce crédit pour le renforcement des marchandises dont sa population a besoin
texts.en: Mr Dame K. is a storekeeper who runs a grocery in the neighborhood Médine Extension in Mbour. He has been in this trade for nearly 4 years. He is single and supports his family. Since Médine is located in the center of an area with dense population, Mr K. decided to invest in the food sector. Therefore he applies for this loan to buy the goods that people need.

loans.use: To buy groceries

loans.name: Ainura's Group

texts.en:
The most important function of all loans is being socially-oriented. Financial help during business struggles is very much appreciated by all creditors.

Ainura E. K., 42, is the treasurer of this group. She is a proud mother of four children, the oldest being 19 years old. Ainura is very proud of her oldest son, because he got accepted to medical school, a profession she always wanted him to pursue. Ainura wants him to save hundreds of lives in the future. Ainura's husband has also chosen a unique sphere to work in; he is an inspector in the regional department of domestic affairs.

Ainura’s businesses are cattle breeding and milk distribution. The family invested 12,000 KGS of its savings to purchase dairy cows and cattle for resale. A good return from this business is always a promising contribution to the family budget. The monthly return from the business is about 3,000 KGS, which is spent on cattle feed, milk transportation and the family's use. Ainura sees a very promising future for her business because she’s looking forward to becoming partners with local milk product firms and individual retailers. The purpose of this loan is to purchase furniture for Ainura's house. She is thankful to all lenders and promises to repay the loan without any violation. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase furniture for the house

loans.name: Piere

texts.en:
Piere is 33 years old and married with two children. For the past 15 years, he has worked as a car mechanic. Piere opened his own garage in 2009 and is well known in his region. He works hard to provide for his family's future and seeks perfection in his business. 

Piere is requesting his first loan from Al Majmoua to buy new tools for his business, such as a car scanner and a carbon dioxide testing machine. Piere’s clients are friends, neighbors, and community members. His high quality of work helps to improve and expand his business. In the future, Piere hopes to expand his business to specialize in certain kinds of cars or services to attract more clients.

loans.use: to buy tools

loans.name: Benkola Group

texts.fr:
Mariées majoritairement dans des familles monogames avec en moyenne 40 ans et 5 enfants, les huit membres du groupe Benkola habitent le quartier Pelengana sud, chef lieu d’une commune rurale dans la région de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali). Elles se sont connues à travers leurs activités génératrices de revenus au marché de Pelengana. Les membres du groupe font le commerce de céréales, d’habillements (chemises, T-shirt et bazins),  de jus locaux, de colliers et des fruits (banane et orange). 
Dans le besoin d’augmenter leur fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont intégré Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 1er prêt solidaire.
Madame Kotimi  Dembélé est connue à Pelengana Nord pour sa vente de fruits de toutes sortes. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 200 kg de banane et 3 sacs d’orange. Elle se ravitaille en fruits avec les forains de Koutiala en gros. La revente se fait au comptant et à crédit, à domicile, en ambulant et au marché de Pelengana à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Madame Kotimi  Dembélé  espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 18.800FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et prendre en charge les besoins du foyer. 
Elle ambitionne devenir grossiste dans ce partenariat avec Soro Yiriwaso.
texts.en:
Benkola Group is composed of eight married women, who on average are 40 years old and have five children. Most of them live in monogamous families in Pelengana Sud, the administrative center of a rural municipality in the region of Ségou (fourth administrative region of Mali). They came to know each other when they ran their businesses at the market in Pelengana. The group members sell cereals, clothes (shirts, T-shirts and basins), local fruit juice, necklaces and fruit (bananas and oranges).

Faced with the need to increase their working capital, the group members joined the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now at their first solidarity loan.

Mrs Kotimi Dembélé is known in Pelengana Nord for her diversified fruit stall. She intends to use her loan to buy 200 kilograms of bananas and 3 sacks of oranges. She gets her supplies from wholesalers at the market in Koutiala and retails her goods, for cash or credit, from her home, or hawking in the streets, or at the market in Pelengana to a clientele made up of women and men.

Mrs Kotimi Dembélé expects to make an average profit of 18,800 CFA francs a month, which will be reinvested in her business and spent to provide for her family. Her ambition is to become a wholesaler thanks to her partnership with Soro Yiriwaso.

loans.use: To buy fruit

loans.name: Tilek Kurmanbekov's Group

texts.en:
It is amazing to see people who fall in life but then find the courage and strength to get up and continue their way to success. These people set examples and are inspiration for those who follow them.

Tilek K., 46, is the leader of the “Tilek K. Group.” He is a resident of a small town called Karabalta and has a grown daughter. His wife is a realtor in a company in Bishkek, the capital of Kyrgyzstan. Tilek works in a heat and energy generating center. His hard work and persistence helped him to overcome a very challenging path to this career. Right after college graduation he became a master of technological maintenance and found this job. Sixteen years of work has brought him experience and knowledge that he is sure will help him in future. 

Currently, Tilek’s monthly income is 8,000 KGS, but unfortunately, he and his family cannot manage to save as their expenses are increasing rapidly due to high inflation. Tilek has applied for a loan from Kiva to purchase a refrigerator. He expects his income to increase soon, so he is confident of repaying the loan in time. In future, Tilek would like to buy a new house and an automobile.


        --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – people (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a  video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 


If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase a refrigerator

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel is a 35-year-old craftsman who is a member of the Kibera Upendo group with Faulu Kenya. For the past ten years, he has run Samuel Crafts to earn a living. Samuel makes bangles, rings, necklaces, and spoons made of bones. So far, he has managed to employ two people in his business. 

Samuel is requesting a loan of 25,000 KES to buy a bench cylinder and raw materials such as bones. Using previous loans through Faulu Kenya, Samuel has improved his business. In the future, he hopes to open other business outlets.

loans.use: to buy a bench cylinder and raw materials

loans.name: Gulmira's Group

texts.en:
Gulmira A., 47, is a leader of this group. She is married and has three children. Her husband is a head of “aiyl okmotu”, which in Kyrgyz means a village. He is responsible for all the activities of the village, its security and the development of business. That makes Gulmira feel responsible too. 

Gulmira is a teacher of Russian language and literature in local high school. Unfortunately, a teachers’ salary is just a little bit above the minimum wage level. Because it’s far from enough to make a living, most teachers look for a second job or start a small business. Gulmira saves most of her salary to pay the tuition of her two college aged children.  Additionally to her work in school, Gulmira also breeds livestock to resell. Her business was started 20 years ago with the purchase of a young calf for 5000 soms. Gulmira raised the calf and resold it, for a generated profit she bought another one. Following this strategy, Gulmira has accomplished a lot, and considerably increased the number of her cattle. Now she’s built a paddock for cattle and provides good living conditions for the cattle. The purpose of the loan is to buy additional livestock and resell them at a good price. The anticipated profit will be spent on making major repairs at her house.

        --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). 

MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase livestock.

loans.name: Djiguisseme Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes du groupe Djiguisseme sont mariées majoritairement dans des familles monogames avec en moyenne 45 ans et 7 enfants. Elle habitent le quartier Pelengana sud, chef lieu d’une commune rurale dans la région de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de leurs activités génératrices de revenus au marché de Pelengana. Les membres du groupe font le commerce de céréales (mil et riz),  des galettes à base de mil et d’habillements (pagnes wax, chemises et bazins). 
Dans le but d’augmenter leur fonds de commerce et de se ravitailler au comptant, les membres du groupe ont connu Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 8ème cycle de prêt solidaire.
Madame Mariama  Djiré est une vendeuse de céréales qui compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter cinq sacs de riz avec les forains de Niono au grand marché de Ségou en gros. Elle revend au comptant et à crédit, à domicile et au marché de Pelengana à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Madame Mariama Djiré espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 35.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité, prendre en charge les besoins du foyer et les soins de santé des enfants. 
Elle ambitionne acheter un lot à usage d’habitation à Ségou.
texts.en:
Djiguisseme Group (“Hope”) is composed of four married women, who on average are 45 years old and have seven children. Most of them live in monogamous families in Pelengana Sud, the administrative center of a rural municipality in the region of Ségou (fourth administrative region of Mali). They came to know each other through ties of kinship and when they ran their businesses at the market in Pelengana. The group members sell cereals (millet and rice), waffles made from millet, and clothes (wax pagnes, shirts and basins).

Faced with the need to increase their working capital and inventory paying cash down, the group members joined the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now at their eighth solidarity loan.

Mrs Mariama Djiré sells cereals. She intends to use her loan to buy 5 sacks of rice from wholesalers in Niono at the market in Ségou. She retails her goods, for cash or credit, from her home and at the market in Pelengana to a clientele made up of women and men.

Mrs Mariama Djiré expects to make an average profit of 35,000 CFA francs a month, which will be reinvested in her business and spent to pay for household expenses and health care for her children. Her ambition is to buy a plot of land and have her own house in Ségou.

loans.use: To buy rice

loans.name: Deggo Book Ligguey Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité DEGGO BOOK LIGGUEY est créé depuis trois ans. Il est composé de 09 femmes. Ces femme prône l'entente au sein de leur groupe. C'est ce qui leur a permis d'être très proche et son complice également dans leurs activités de façon général. Elles s'investissent toutes dans le petit commerce, achètent les produits au même endroit et fixe les même prix de vente.

Madame Marie Boya D. à droite sur la photo et levant la main est responsable du groupe. Elle est âgée de 33 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 04 enfants en charge. 

Elle s'active dans la vente d'huile de palme, de balaies, de citron. 

Les prêts qu'elle a contracté au près de CAURIE-MF lui ont permis d'étendre son marché vers la capitale du pays (Dakar)

Elle participe mieux dans la prise en charge de l'éducation de ses enfants. Elle soutien également son époux dans les charges familiales de façon générale.
texts.en:
The Deggo Book Ligguey solidarity group was created three years ago. It is composed of nine women. These women advocate harmony within their group, and this allowed them to feel very close and cooperative in their business activities. They have all invested in small stores, buy their products in one place and set the same price.

Mrs Marie Boya D., standing right in the picture and raising her hand, chairs the group. She is 33 years old, married and the mother of four children in her care. She sells palm oil, brooms and lemons. The loans she was granted so far by Caurie Microfinance enabled her to expand her activity right up to Dakar, the capital of the country. Now she participates more in the education of her children. She also supports her husband with general household expenses.

loans.use: To expand and promote her small business

loans.name: Djiguitougou Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Djiguitougou est composé de quatre femmes mariées (2 monogames et 2 polygames) ayant en moyenne 44 ans et 3 enfants. Elles habitent toutes dans le quartier Hamdallaye de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de leurs activités de petit commerce dans le marché Château de Ségou. Les membres du groupe font l’achat et la vente de pagnes wax, d’habits pour enfants et de poisson fumé. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce et de se ravitailler au comptant, les membres du groupe ont adhéré au programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 11ème prêt solidaire.
Madame Hawa  Kané compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 200 kg de poissons fumés. Elle est ravitaillée en poisson en gros et à domicile par des fournisseurs (des femmes de pêcheurs de Markala). La revente se fait en détail, au comptant et à crédit à domicile et au marché Château à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes. 
Madame Hawa  Kané espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 50 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité, prendre en charge certains besoins du foyer et les soins de santé et la scolarisation des enfants. 
Elle ambitionne acheter un lot à usage d’habitation dans ce partenariat avec Soro Yiriwaso.
texts.en:
The Djiguitougou group is made up of four married women (two monogamous and two polygamous) who average 44 years of age with three children each. They all live in the Hamdallaye district of Ségou (Mali's fourth administrative region) and got to know each other through relatives and their small business activities in Ségou's Château market. The members of the group buy and sell "pagnes wax" (highly decorative and colourful West African pieces of fabric), children's clothing and smoked fish. 

With the aim of increasing their working capital and getting fresh supplies for cash, the members of the group joined Soro Yiriwaso's loan program and they are now on their eleventh group loan. 

Mrs. Hawa Kané is planning to use her loan to buy 200kg of smoked fish. She gets her supplies of fish wholesale and at home from suppliers (fishermen's wives from Markala). She resells them on a retail basis, for cash and on credit, at home and at the Château market to a customer base made up principally of women. 

Mrs. Kané is hoping to make an average monthly profit of 50,000FCFA with this loan, and she will use this profit to reinvest in her business and to cover certain household needs as well as her children's health and schooling expenses. Her ambition is to buy, in collaboration with Soro Yiriwaso, a piece of land to live on.

loans.use: To purchase smoked fish

loans.name: Asma Shahzadi

texts.en:
Asma Shahzadi lives in the historic city of Lahore, Pakistan. Lahore is the second largest city in Pakistan and known for its history and culture. She lives there with her family in the area of Daata town in a three-roomed brick house. She moved here 4 years ago with her family. She is a 26 year old lady and has no children yet. Her husband has a welding shop. He welds different spare parts and iron items on order. He also makes iron windows and doors for his customers. He is well known among his clients due to his good behavior and services. 

Asma lives in a combined family home with her in-laws. One of her brothers-in-law works in a factory while the other has a construction supplies selling business. 

Asma is a caring lady, prefers to stay at home and does her household responsibilities. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further improvement of her husband’s business. With the loan, he will purchase iron in bulk to offer quality services to his clients and to fulfill their orders to make more profits. Asma is very hopeful that through the growth of her husband’s business she will be able to enhance her family’s living standard. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained a good credit behavior and never missed any meetings.

loans.use: To buy iron for welding business.

loans.name: Samira

texts.en:
Samira is a 62 year old married woman living in Chtoura with her husband and two kids. Samira has worked, since 2002, in making and selling Saj bread. Saj bread is a flat, round bread baked on an upside-down iron wok hot surface. It is traditional Lebanese bread. 

Samira works hard to help her husband earn their family's income. In addition to her work in Saj, she works as a tailor. When we asked her why she does this, her answer was that a good woman must stand next to her husband and help in every way she can,"we have children to raise and we have to provide them with the best we can."  

Samira is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua for the first time, in order to buy necessary raw materials for her business. Most of her clients are neighbors, friends and passers by. She hopes to open a big bakery in the future.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for her business.

loans.name: Turdukan's Group

texts.en:
A very common challenge for all entrepreneurs is inflation. Almost no one stays untouched by it. The costs of operating a business rise, which forces entrepreneurs to raise prices for products and services, which further scares away some of the customers. 

Turdukan Z., 27, is a member of this group. She is single and doesn’t have any financial dependents. Her father has always been a cattle breeder so Turdukan inherited love for animals and the skills of taking care of them. When she began leading an independent lifestyle, her father recommended for her to start cattle breeding on her own. Without any hesitation Turdukan agreed and bought a couple of heads of cattle. Year by year Turdukan’s assets of cattle are growing in number. It creates a new problem for her. How to solve transportation issues? When she had few heads of cattle, that was not such a big issue, but now it requires a bigger truck and higher costs. So Turdukan turned to Mol Bulak Finance for help. Being offered a loan by Kiva, she was in heaven from happiness. It is such a great deal for her. Turdukan really hopes to get a loan which she plans to spend on buying additional cattle and a truck for transporting them to a local cattle yard. 

         --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle.

loans.name: Faïda Group

texts.fr:
Les dix femmes du groupe Faïda sont toutes mariées dans des familles monogames avec en moyenne 32 ans et 4 enfants. Elles habitent toutes dans le quartier Hamdallaye de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers leurs activités génératrices de revenus dans le marché Château de Ségou. Les membres du groupe font le commerce des habits de la friperie, du riz, du savon, de l’encens et des légumes (laitue et tomate). 
Dans le but d’augmenter leur fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 2ème prêt solidaire.
Madame Mamou T., a une grande réputation dans la préparation et la vente d’encens surtout du côté des nouvelles mariées. Elle  compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 1 kg de magnonkisseni, 3 bouteilles d’eau de Cologne et 6 tubes de parfums. Pour fabriquer l’encens, elle imbibe le magnonkisseni dans l’eau de Cologne pendant une semaine au moins, ensuite elle l’assaisonne avec ses différentes qualités de parfums. L’encens ainsi préparé est reparti entre les bouteilles destinées à la vente. Elle se ravitaille en ses matières de base au grand marché de Ségou. La vente se fait au comptant et à crédit, à domicile et au marché Château à une clientèle composée généralement de femmes. 
Madame Mamou T. espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 20.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et assurer les petits besoins du foyer. 
A l’image des autres membres du groupe, elle ambitionne devenir grossiste dans la préparation et vente de l’encens dans ce partenariat avec Soro Yiriwaso.
texts.en:
The ten members of the Faïda solidarity group are married women who live in monogamous families. They average 32 years of age and four children each. They all live in the Hamdallaye district of the Ségou region (fourth administrative region of Mali), and met through their income-generating activities at the Château market, in Ségou. They sell second-hand clothing, rice, soap, incense and vegetables (lettuce and tomatoes). 

In order to expand their businesses, the group decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution and are on their second group loan. 

Mrs. Mamou T. enjoys a great reputation in the preparation and sale of incense, especially among new brides. She plans to use her loan to buy 1 kg of magnonkisseni grains, 3 bottles of Cologne, and 6 tubes of perfume. To make incense, she soaks the magnonkisseni in Cologne for at least a week, then adds the various perfumes. The incense is then poured into bottles to be sold. Mrs. T. gets her supplies at the Grand market of Ségou. She sells for cash and credit, from her home and at the Château market, to a clientele composed mostly of women. 

With this loan, Mrs. T. hopes to earn an average monthly profit of 20,000 FCFA to be used for the needs of the household and for reinvestment in her business. Like the other group members, she aspires to become a wholesaler in the preparation and sale of incense through her collaboration with Soro Yiriwaso.

loans.use: Purchase of raw materials for the preparation of incense

loans.name: Lorn

texts.en: Lorn R., 38, is a local farmer who lives in the province of Kompong Cham. Lorn R. can earn about $1.75 per day. Her husband is a 38-year-old farmer who also assists her in the farming business, making an average profit of $1.75 also. They have four single children; three of whom are still studying in the local school while the other one works with her aunt as a mobile phone seller in the Poiy Pet City. Lorn R. is applying for a loan to hire a machine to plow farmland and to pay for harvest costs of previously hired domestic laborers.

loans.use: To hire a machine to plow farmland and to pay for harvest costs (hired, domestic laborers).

loans.name: Gulkiya's Group

texts.en:
Gulkiya T., 27, is involved in retailing consumer goods in a market in her hometown of Kerben. She is the treasurer of her group. She is married and has a seven-month-old toddler. While she is at work, she relies on a nanny to look after him. Gulkiya’s husband had to leave to go to Russia because he was offered a much better job. Both of them hope that soon things will be figured out and that they will have a chance to bring the whole family together. 

Every morning Gulkiya says good bye to her child until the evening, and leaves for work as early as possible. Retailing consumer goods is highly competitive, leading people to come up with new ideas for promoting their products. Every seller has his or her own techniques ranging from allowing customers to bargain to making gifts to customers. Gulkiya believes in a saying “the early bird catches the worm” and tries to open up early to attract early customers wandering in a market. Gulkiya faces severe competition, so she does her best to stand out from the crowd. 

Gulkiya's parents operated the business throughout their whole life. They gave Gulkiya the business ten years ago when. By watching her parents serve customers, Gulkiya already knew the successful techniques of retail. Ten years of hard work has brought its fruits. Gulkiya made a gift to her husband. She bought an automobile that he was dreaming of for a very long time. At this moment the business generates a monthly income of 7,000 soms for Gulkiya. She plans to spend the requested loan on buying more consumer goods. Over the next months she expects to have high demand and truly believes she will be repay the loan on time and without any violations.
      
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase consumer goods for trade

loans.name: Anipa's Group

texts.en:
Last year farming entrepreneurs became very vulnerable because of the political instability that occurred in Kyrgyzstan and caused a closure of borders with the neighboring countries. Businessmen lost a significant portion of their customers. Since those events entrepreneurs are recovering slowly and going back to a normal life. 
 
Anipa J., 56, is a leader of this group. She is a widow and lives with her four-year-old grandson. Anipa’s grandson goes to a daycare, and Anipa devotes the whole day to a business of cattle breeding. Two years ago her son recommended that she start this business, and since then she hasn’t regretted doing so once. Anipa buys young calves, breeds them and resells them in a local market. She gathered a group with three other stock breeders and applied for a loan from Kiva through its partner Mol Bulak Finance. The proceeds from this investment will help her to improve living conditions for her grandson. Anipa also runs a dairy business and sells milk to a local market every morning. Her primary challenges were high costs for transportation and feeding the cattle, but despite those hardships Anipa believes she will overcome all challenges and expand her business. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Mbenda

texts.fr: Mademoiselle Mbenda D. est une femme célibataire qui travaille dans le milieu du commerce. Elle vend des habits,des chaussures et divers produits alimentaires. Elle achéte ses produits au niveau de la Gambie.mademoiselle D. est dans le commerce depuis 1997.Elle a sollicité ce prêt pour renforcer son activité commerciale et diversifier ses chances
texts.en: Miss Mbenda D. is a single woman who works as a vendor. She sells clothing, shoes and groceries. She stocks up in Gambia. Miss Deng has been in this business since 1997. She is seeking a loan in order to bolster her business and increase her opportunities.

loans.use: Retail

loans.name: Nazira's Group

texts.en:
Rises in prices first hit the most vulnerable classes of the population. Rural areas and those who financially depend on trade suffer the most. 

Nazira O., 27, is a member of this group. She is married to a farmer and has three children, the oldest of whom is 8 years old. Her kids are in school and daycare while she is at work. Following the recommendations of her sister five years ago, Nazira invested a start-up capital of 20,000 soms in retailing consumer goods in a market in the small town of Kerben.

She is happy with how she is running the business despite the challenges she faces with transportation of wholesale goods. Nazira’s home town of Kerben is several hours away from the capital Bishkek, where she gets the wholesale products. This long distance affects the quality of goods and her ability to cover costs. In order to attract more customers she applied for a loan from Kiva that would help her to broaden the assortment of her products.
