Lubna is hopeful that her brother-in-law will be able to increase his monthly profits and she will easily be able to return the loan with the help of increased profits.

She is a new loan applicant and hopeful that it will be a profitable experience for her family.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine for sewing business.

loans.name: Hau

texts.en:
Hau T. T. is a 53 year old woman, who lives in Tuan le village. Since receiving her first loan in 2004, she not only invested in doing farming, but also running a small shop that sells ready cooked food in the local market. Her extra job became the main source of her daily income. 

Participating for 7 years in SEDA, she has always been a good repayer. To develop her business more, she wants to have a loan of 9,810,000 VND  to buy a glass table to put food inside to ensure the food safety requirement is met.

loans.use: To buy a glass table to put food inside to ensure the food safety requirement is met.

loans.name: Ha

texts.en:
Ha T. N. is 35 years old with 2 children who are at secondary school. She has been a farmers for many years, and her main activity focuses on growing flowers and vegetables. Every day, she takes them to the centre market to sell wholesale, and provides a stable income from this activity.

She joined the credit program in 2004, and has received 7 loans, which she has used very effectively in running her business. Currently, she wants to have a loan of 9,374,000 VND to buy more fertilizer and some equipment to increase the product quality.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizer and some equipment to increase quality.

loans.name: Hanh

texts.en:
Hanh T. D. is 53 years old with 2 children. She is a farmer who grows rice, vegetables, and flowers in a paddy of 2,800 square meters. Her agricultural products are of good quality so they are sold at the best price. This provides her with a good income to cover her family's living expenses.

She joined Seda credit program in 2004, and has really made full use of the loans to expand her business. Currently, she wants to have a loan of 8,502,000 VND to buy more kinds of small trees and fertilizer.

loans.use: To buy more kind of trees and fertilizer.

loans.name: Tho

texts.en:
Tho T. N. is 49 years old and lives in Tuan le village. She has a small grocery shop  in Dong anh Centre market.  Her business earns 80,000 VND per day. This income helps her a lot in managing her family life.

Since joining the credit program in 2004, she has used the loans to expand effectively. With the hope of having a loan of 8,066,000 VND , she plans to  buy more commodities and new products to meet the demands of customers.

loans.use: To buy more commodities and new products to meet the demands  of customers.

loans.name: Lieu

texts.en:
Lieu T. H. is 51 years old with 4 children. Two of them attend high school. She has lived in Tuan le for a long time, and because it is an area known for its land and producing clean vegetables, she is an experienced farmer. She has a paddy of 3,600 square meters, in which high quality kinds of vegetable are grown. Every month, she can earn 3,000,000 VND profit from selling these products.

She has been a client of Seda credit program since 2004, and is a good borrower. Currently, she wants to have a loan of 8,502,000 VND to buy fertilizer and seeds to prepare for the next crop.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seeds to prepare for next crop.

loans.name: Quyen

texts.en:
Quyen T. T. is 35 years old with 2 children who are at high school and secondary school. She has a small shop that sells vegetable and fruit in the local market. Her business creates 100,000 VND profit, and it makes it easier to manage family life when her husband is out of work.

Being a client of SeDa credit program since 2004, she has very effectively used the loans for running the business. She hopes that for this loan cycle, she can borrow 9,374,000 VND to improve her shop and buy more products to meet the demands of customers.

loans.use: To improve her shop by buying more products to meet customers' demands.

loans.name: El Cacique Group

texts.es:
L. señora María Guadalupe Mondragón Ángel, pertenece al grupo llamado “EL CACIQUE”, comenta que le pusieron ese nombre al grupo porque muy cerca D. su localidad se encuentra un cerro con ese nombre y por eso decidieron llamar al grupo con ese nombre. Doña Lupita como es conocida por sus vecinos y conocidos es originaria D. L. localidad D. L. Segunda Manzana D. Nicolás Romero ubicado en el Estado D. Michoacán,  elL. cuenta con 27 año D. edad y comenta que no estudio debido a que sus papás nunca L. mandaron a L. escueL., elL. está casada con el señor Gilberto el cual es albañil y tienen 5 hijos D. nombres Juan José D. 9 años D. edad, Gilberto D. 6 años ambos estudiantes D. primaria, Valeria D. 5 años que estudia Preescolar y el pequeño Luis D. 6 meses. ElL. está pidiendo un préstamo a L. financiera para L. invertir en gallinas, comenta que las cría y engorda en dos meses para después venderlas a clientes que tiene en su localidad. Doña Lupita comenta que le va a servir D. mucho el préstamo ya que podrá comprar más gallinas y tendría más clientes porque los vendería por mayoreo sus animales y tendría más ganancias. L. meta es poder surtirles a las personas D. su localidad que se dedican a vender pollo a un buen precio para que ellos no se trasladen hasta Zitácuaro a comprar los pollos, y también hacer un gallinero más granD. porque el que tiene ya no le caben. 
Rosa María Chávez C., es parte del grupo “EL CACIQUE” tiene 21 años y estudio hasta el tercer año D. secundaria, después elL. por cuenta propia se metió a estudiar para cultora D. belleza ya que desD. que iba en L. secundaria le llamaba L. atención el peinar a sus compañeras D. clase y otra que cerca D. su casa no había estéticas por eso decidió estudiar esa pequeña carrera. Rosy como es conocida en su localidad es soltera y vive con sus papas, elL. tiene una pequeña estética en su casa, elL. hace cortes D. pelo a damas, caballeros y niños, también pinta el pelo, hacer rayitos, bases, peinados para novias, quinceañeras etc. Tiene con su estética aproximadamente 4 años, y decidió emprender este negocio porque cerca D. su casa no avía estéticas y para ayudar a sus papas con los gastos D. L. casa. ElL. comprara con su préstamo tintes, líquidos, peines, cepillos y lo necesario para su estética, comenta que surte sus productos en México y en Zitacuaro Michoacán. L. meta que tiene para su negocio es ampliar su local ya que es muy pequeño,  pintarlo y rotularlo para que se dé a conocer más e incrementar el número D. clientas que elL. tiene.

Las otras 16 integrantes se llaman Isidra López Avilés, Nemesia Jerónimo González, María Cristina Rincón Jerónimo, Laura Cecilia López T., María Teresa López G., Alicia M. D. L. C., Araceli C. A., Alejandra Temahuaya S., Jazmín C. A., Belén G. A., Elsa C. R., María Santos C. Juárez, Ma. Guadalupe A. G., Rosalinda M. C., Alberta M. A., Rosalba López F.,  ellas quieren los préstamos para invertir en  L. compra
D. frutas y legumbres, pastura alimento para vacas, tienda D. abarrotes, dulces y frituras, pollos y guajolotes para su venta.
texts.en:
María Guadalupe Mondragón Ángel belongs to the 'El Cacique' group.  She says that the members gave the group this name because very close to their town there is a hill with this name so they decided to give the group the same name.

Lupita, as she is known by her neighbors and acquaintances, is from the town of L. Segunda Manzana D. Nicolás Romero which is located in the State of Michoacán.  She is 27 years old and she tells us that she didn't study because her parents never sent her to school.  She is married to Gilberto, who is a construction worker, and they have 5 children: 9 year-old Juan José and 6 year-old Gilberto, who are both attending elementary school, 5 year-old Valeria who is in pre-school and 6 month-old Luis.  She is requesting a loan to invest in buying hens.  She says that she raises the hens and fattens them over the course of two months.  She then sells them to customers in her town.  Lupita tells us that the loan will be very useful to her as she will be able to buy more hens and will have more customers because she will sell her animals wholesale and will make more profits.

Lupita's goal is to be able to proviD. her animals to the people in her town who sell chicken at a good price so that they don't have to go to Zitácuaro to buy their chickens.  She would also like to have a bigger coop because she can no longer fit all her hens in her existing coop.

Rosa María Chávez C. is a member of the "El Cacique" group.  She is 21 years old and studied up to the third year of high school.  She then decided to pay her way through beauty school, since while in high school she had enjoyed doing her friends' hair, and she also realized that there were not any estheticians working in her neighborhood. Rosy, as she is know locally, is single and lives with her parents. She has a small salon in her house, and does hair cuts for women, men and children, and also does coloring, braiding, and styling for special events such as birthday parties. She has been working in her salon roughly four years and decided to start the business because there was nothing similar close to her house, and she also wanted to help her parents with household expenses. With her loan, she will buy locally produced dyes, combs, brushes and other necessary goods for her salon. Her goal is to increase her business, given that it is currently very small, to paint her salon and to put up a sign so as to increase the number of clients that she has. 

The other 16 members of this group are: Isidra López Avilés, Nemesia Jerónimo González, María Cristina Rincón Jerónimo, Laura Cecilia López T., María Teresa López G., Alicia M. D. L. C., Araceli C. A., Alejandra T. S., Jazmín C. A., Belén G. A., Elsa C. R., María Santos C. Juárez, Ma. Guadalupe A. G., Rosalinda M. D. L. C., Alberta M. A. and Rosalba López F..  They are requesting loans to invest in buying fruit for making fruit salads and groceries.  They will also invest in a beauty business, a dairy business and a fruit and vegetable business.

loans.use: To buy chickens to raise and sell

loans.name: Maguellitos Group

texts.es:
El señor Sebastián Pérez Hernández, vive en la localidad de San Juan Municipio de Coapilla Estado de Chiapas México, vive en unión libre con la señora  Elena Pérez Pérez,  Y tiene un hijo  de nombre Sebastián quien trabaja para apoyarlos  con los ingresos de la casa.

         El préstamo que solicito es para invertirlo en la compra y venta de ganados como son  las becerros y vacas, para engordarlo y luego venderlo de nuevo en la misma región, con esta actividad le va bien ya que nos cometa que lleva tres años  y le ha dado buenos resultados.

        Inicio por si solo ya que  para salir adelante con su familia tenía que  tener de donde sostenerse  y de dónde sacar los ingreso para sobrevivir y con el préstamo se ha estado ayudando mucho.
 
        De cada venta que realiza lo ahorra comprando mas ganado para que cuando lo necesite esté disponible para venderlo de nuevo y así seguir trabajando para su familia que  aun que es pequeña  quiere darle lo mejor.
 
      Cometa que llano pide  nada más  solo que dios que le siga prestando vida para seguir trabajando  y tener lo más valioso que es su familia.

     Es integrante del grupo "Maguellitos" y se integra de tres personas un  hombre y dos mujeres, la razón del nombre es porque en ese lugar hay matas de maguey.

    Los integrantes del grupo son las siguientes:

   María Méndez López: invierte el préstamo en la compra de becerros para venderlo en la misma región.

   Míguela Hernández López: invierte el préstamo en la compra de vacas y becerros.

    Sebastián Pérez Hernández: invierte el préstamo en la compra y venta de becerros y vacas.
texts.en:
Sebastián Pérez Hernández lives in San Juan neighborhood, in the town of Coapilla, in the State of Chiapas, Mexico.  He lives with his partner Elena Pérez Pérez and has a son called Sebastián who works to help them with their household finances.

Sebastián requested a loan to invest in buying and selling livestock such as lambs and cows which he fattens and then sells in his region.  His business is doing well.  He tells us that he has been in the business for three years and it has provided him with good results.

He started out in this business on his own initiative since, in order to get his family ahead in life, he had to have some means of support, some way of making income so that they could survive.  His loans have been helping him a lot.

Every time he makes a sale, he saves the money and buys more livestock so that when he needs to, he has animals available to sell again.  In this way he continues working for his family.  Although his family is small, he wants to provide them with the best.

Sebastián tells us that he no longer needs anything, only for God to continue granting him with life so that he can continue working and to have the most valuable thing which is his family.

Sebastián is a member of the "Maguellitos" group which has three members: one man and two women.  They gave the group this name because where they live there are 'maguey' (American aloe) plants.

The members of the group are:

María Méndez López, who will invest her loan in buying lambs to sell in her region
Míguela Hernández López, who will invest her loan in buying cows and lambs
stián Pérez Hernández, who will invest his loan in buying and selling lambs and cows.

loans.use: To buy livestock such as lambs and cows to fatten and then sell in the same region

loans.name: Los Ositos Group

texts.es:
El siguiente grupo está ubicado en la comunidad de Yondesé del cedero, San Jose del rincon, la comunidad es de escasos recursos economicos, ahora se ve ya pavimentada con un poco de obra publica realiza por las autoridades del municipio pero antes era puro polvo arena suelta, las casas son en su mayoria de adobe y muchas mas de madera, la gente no sabe leer a exepción de los niños que van a la escuelas, todavia la mayor parte de la comunidad es arena pues lo unico pavimentado es la carretera principal, la gente es muy sencilla humilde, atenta y educada no pierde las buenas costumbres que se tenian antes, el grupo de "Los Ositos" lo integran 8 personas 7 mujeres y 1 hombre, todos ellos vecinos de la comunidad y amigos, sobre la actividad economica realizada en esta comunidad es la cria de animales, (puercos, borregos, caballos reces y aves), el transporte sigue siendo el caballo, aunque si pasa el camion pero no muy seguido, los nombres de las personas que integran el grupo son los siguientes:
1.-Herminia C. U. de 39 años de edad
2.-Antonia C. C. de 58 años de edad
3.-Consuelo P. U. de 58 años de edad
4.- Catalina U. C. de 51 años de edad
5.-Sandra García H. de 28 años de edad
6.-Rocio S. R. de 32 años de edad
7.-Leonardo C. C. de 33 años de edad
8.-Ana Maria F. C. de 35 años de edad

Los integrantes del grupo desidieron llamarse así porque no sabian como ponerse y los nombres que elegian ya los tenian otros grupos, y una hija de un integrante traia un oso de peluche abrazando por eso se llamaron de esa manera el grupo.
La representante del grupo es la señora Rocio, doña Rocio nos cuenta que su grupo lleva años de conocerse y ya habian trabajado juntos antes, nos dice que todos son personas confiables y trabajadores por esa razon necesitaban la ayuda economica para salir adelante y echarle ganas, todo su grupo se dedica a la cria de animales de engorda para venderlos, su negocio es compra-venta de borregos, tambien tiene una pequeña tienda en su misma casa de refrescos y algo de dulces y galletas, cria pollos guajolotes y caballos tiene un poco de todo que le ayuda a ir saliendo con los gastos en su casa adelante. doña Rocio nos comenta que se le hace dificil darles de comer a los animales porque la pastura se acaba pronto y tinen que comprar, nos dice que el prestamo le ayuda mucho ya que puede comprar los animales que quiere alcontado y hay mayores ganancias porque los dejan mas baratos y ella misma los cria y los engorda, doña Rocio es casada ya tiene 15 años viviendo con su esposo en casa propia, tiene 4 niños, dos niños estudian y dos mas estan pequeños todavia no van a la escuela, el esposo de doña Rocio trabaja en la ciudad de México porque no encontro trabajo cerca de su casa, viene cada 8 o 15 dias a visitar a su familia.
texts.en:
The following group is located in the community of Yondesé del Cerdero, San José del Rincón.  It is a community of very limited economic resources.  The community has been paved through a little bit of work which was carried out by the town authorities but before it was just dust and loose sand.  The houses are mainly made of adobe and many are also made from wood.  The people do not know how to read, except the children who attend school. Most of the community is still just sand as the only bit that was paved was the main road.  The people are very simple, humble, kind and polite.  They haven't lost the good manners that they had in the past.

The 'Los Ositos' (Little Bears) group has 8 members: 7 women and 1 man.  All of the members are neighbors and friends.  The main business activity carried out in this community is raising livestock (pigs, sheep, cows and poultry).  The mode of transportation continues being horses.  Although the truck does pass through it isn't very frequent.

The names of the members of this group are as follows:
1.-Herminia C. U. - 39 years old
2.-Antonia C. C. - 58 years old
3.-Consuelo P. U. - 58 years old
4.- Catalina U. C. - 51 years old
5.-Sandra García H. - 28 years old
6.-Rocio S. R. - 32 years old
7.-Leonardo C. C. - 33 years old
8.-Ana Maria F. C. - 35 years old

The members of this group gave themselves the name 'Los Ositos' (Little Bears) because they didn't know what name to give their group and the names they chose were already taken by other groups.   One of the member's daughters would bring with her a teddy bear that she would cuddle and so they gave their group this name.

The group's representative is Rocio.  Rocio tells us that the members of her group have known each other for years and they have worked together before.  She tells us that they are all trustworthy and hard-working people.  They need financial help to get ahead in life.  All the members of her group raise livestock which they fatten and then sell.  Her business is buying and selling lambs.  She also has a small store in her home where she sells soft drinks and also some candy and cookies.  She raises turkeys and horses.  She has a little of everything which helps her to cover her household expenses.

Rocio tells us that it is becoming hard to feed her animals because the pasture will be finished soon and they have to buy.  She tells us that the loans help her a lot because she can buy the animals she wants for cash and this makes her more profit because she can acquire them more cheaply.  She raises the animals and fattens them herself.    Rocio is married and has been living with her husband in their own home for 15 years.  She has 4 children.  Two of her children are in school and the other two are still too young for school.  Rocio's husband works in Mexico City because he couldn't find work near home.  He comes home to visit his family every week or fortnight.

loans.use: To invest in lambs

loans.name: El Valerio Group

texts.es:
El siguiente grupo se llama "El Valerio" pertenece a San Jose del rincon, los nueve integrantes son vecinos y parientes D. la comunidad D. el Valerio, desidieron llamarse asi porque a alos integrantes les da gusto llevar el nombre D. su pueblo, nos dicen que no saben que significa el nombre pero les gusta mucho como suena, la comunidad D. el Valerio es muy pequeña, hay pocos habitantes, la mayoria son gente comerciante pero aun asi tambien crian animales se dedican a la agricultura, este grupo es D. 9 integrantes, son 8 mujeres y 1 hombre, los nombres D. los integrantes son los siguientes:
1.-Concepcion, J. D. J., 48 años D. edad
2.-Cristina C. R., 51 años D. edad
3.-Beatriz S. J., 22 años D. edad
4.-Patricia J. C., 33 años D. edad
5.-Celedonia J. S., 46 años
6.-Mariela J. J., 24 años edad
7.-Felipa G. S., 23 años
8.- Maria E. C., 45 años D. edad.
9.-Arnulfo U. B., 52 años D. edad.

Los integrantes nos comenta que tienen años D. conocerse y todos son trabajadores y tienen una actividad que realizar diario, son vecinos, la encargada del grupo se llama Mariela, la señora Mariela es líder en su comunidad mucha gente la sigue y apoya propuestas que tenga referente a su comunidad, Doña Mariela se dedica a vender ropa en abonos, los abonos son semanales o quincenales dependiendo como los clientes D. doña Mariela gusten,  lo difícil del negocio D. doña Mariela es que tiene q caminar casa por casa ofreciendo la ropa y además fiarla, porque D. contado nadie paga, la meta que quiere alcanzar es poner un local D. ropa para que le vaya mejor y no se canse tanto, del mismo negocio D. ropa sale para comprar la comida o ropa para sus hijos etc. Doña Mariela ayuda a su esposo con los gastos para que juntos salgan adelante.  Doña Mariela tiene 2 hijos un niño y una niña, estudian el kínder y la primaria, tiene 8 años D. casada, vive con su esposo en casa propia y su esposo se dedica a vender plásticos.
texts.en:
The following group is called "El Valerio" and is located in San José del Rincón.  The nine group members are neighbors and relations from the village of El Valerio.  They decided to give their group this name because they like it having the same name as their village.  They tell us that they don't know what the name means but they really like how it sounds.  The village of El Valerio is very small.  There are very few inhabitants.  Most people sell products but some also raise animals and farm.

This group has 9 members: 8 women and 1 man.  The names of the group's members are as follows:
1.-Concepcion, J. D. J. - 48 years old
2.-Cristina C. R. - 51 years old
3.-Beatriz S. J. - 22 years old
4.-Patricia J. C. - 33 years old
5.-Celedonia J. S. - 46 years old
6.-Mariela J. J. - 24 years old
7.-Felipa G. S. - 23 years old
8.- Maria E. C. - 45 years old
9.-Arnulfo U. B. - 52 years old

The members tell us that they have known each other for years.  They are all hard workers and they have businesses that they carry out every day.  They are all neighbors.

The lady in charge of this group is called Mariela.  Mariela is a leader of her community.  Many people follow her and support her suggestions regarding the community.  Mariela's business is selling clothes on credit.  Instalments can be paid weekly or fortnightly, depending on the preference of her customers.  The difficult thing about Mariela's business is that she has to walk from house to house offering her clothes for sale and she also has to trust her customers because nobody pays cash.  Her goal is to set up a clothes store which wiil be better as it means she won't get so tired.  Through her clothes business, Mariela makes enough money to buy food and clothes for her children.  Mariela helps her husband with their expenses so that they can get ahead in life.  She has 2 children: 1 boy and 1 girl.  The children are studying in kindergarten and elementary school.  Mariela has been married for 8 years.  She lives with her husband in her own home and her husband's business is selling plastic products.

loans.use: To buy and sell clothes

loans.name: Lea

texts.en:
Lea M. is from the village of San Juan, Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. She is 46 years old. Lea is separated from her spouse and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Lea owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, junk foods & toothpaste in the local community. She also makes and sells snack foods like rice cakes. Lea has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Lea joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lea has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and working capital. Lea is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like junked foods & canned goods. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Lea from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell like junked foods & canned goods.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria G. is from the town of Tagbilaran. She is 60 years old, and is married. To make a living, Maria owns and operates a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and reselling assorted fish. Maria works hard to provide for her family.

Maria joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maria has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Maria is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase cellophane and more fish to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase cellophane and more fish to sell.

loans.name: Las Kiwis Group

texts.es: Este grupo solidario se llama Las Kiwis se encuentra localizado en la comunidad de Jaloxtoc, Cd. Ayala, en el estado de Morelos, México, está conformado por 5 integrantes mujeres que se conocen y son vecinas ellas son la señora Sara J. V. va a comprar con su préstamo zapatos y ropa, blusas, pantalones, faldas etc., va a comprar platos, vasos desechables, la señora Margarita T. J. va a comprar zapatos para surtir su pedido, la señora Elizabeth Martínez T. va a comprar cosméticos, zapatos para surtir sus pedidos, la señora María del Refugio T. M. va a comprar abono para abonar su milpa que es de riego, la señora Claudia B. E. va a comprar azúcar, yogurt, queso, refrescos, para surtir su negocio, La señora Claudia B. E. tiene 35 años de edad estudio hasta el 3er, año de secundaria, ella es casada no tiene hijos, ella tiene su negocio de maquinitas de multijuegos , ella solicito su préstamo para comenzar a surtir su tienda de abarrotes va a comprar salchichas, jamón, yogurt, queso añejo, queso de hebra y refrescos y también va a comprar pintura para pintar su casa, su negocio lo inicio hace un año por falta de dinero para que hubiera mas ingresos para su casa, las maquinitas están a comisión le dan un porcentaje, anteriormente vendía picaditas y dobladitas y quiere volver a vender picaditas y dobladitas, su negocio es importante porque le llegan ingresos, tiene dinero para que no le falte nada y su negocio está en su casa y no paga renta, sus clientes son los niños que van a jugar, su negocio enfrenta la competencia de otra persona que tiene maquinitas, las ganancias del negocio las utiliza para comprar la despensa, ella está planeando ampliar su negocio poner su tienda de abarrotes y vender picaditas y dobladitas, y lo piensa lograr con los prestamos, este negocio le ha ayudado económicamente, las mejoras que desea hacer a su vivienda son ponerle piso a su casa, banquetas, remodelar su tanque de agua, sus planes y esperanzas son que su negocio crezca y ponerle piso a su casa, ella está feliz con este préstamo que le van a dar para que su negocio crezca y se dé a conocer.  Las integrantes del grupo quieren decirle a Kiva y Fundación Realidad “Muchas gracias por su ayuda, que baje el interés para que nos alcance y que todo está bien a ver si se puede bajar el interés y que nos sigan prestando”. Jaloxtoc es un pueblo bonito se ve el campo, los cerros, siembran sorgo, maíz, cebolla.
texts.en:
This community bank is called 'Las Kiwis' and it is located in Jaloxtoc, in Ciudad Ayala, in the State of Morelos, Mexico.  It has 5 female members who know each other and are neighbors.  They are Sara J. Valentín, who will use her loan to buy shoes and clothes, blouses, skirts, etc. and disposable plates and cups; Margarita T. J., who will buy shoes to fill an order; Elizabeth Martínez T., who will buy cosmetics and shoes to fill her orders; María del Refugio T. M., who will buy manure to fertilize her irrigated fields and Claudia B. E. who will buy sugar, yoghurt, cheese and soft drinks to stock her business.

Claudia B. E. is 35 years old and studied up to the third year of high school.  She is married and doesn't have any children.  She has a games machine business.  Claudia has requested her loan so that she can start stocking a grocery store.  She will buy sausages, ham, yoghurt, Añejo cheese, Oaxaca cheese and soft drinks.  She will also buy paint so that she can paint her home.

Claudia started her business a year ago as her household needed more income.  She has her games machines on commission and earns a percentage.  She used to sell 'picaditas' (filled cornmeal shells) and 'dobladitas' (a kind of quick bread).  She would like to go back to selling 'picaditas' and 'dobladitas'.  Her business is important because it makes her income.  She has money so that she doesn't want for anything, her business is located in her home and she doesn't pay rent.  Her customers are the children who come to play on the machines.  Her business has competition from another person who has games machines.

Claudia uses the profits from her business to buy food.  She is planning to expand her business, set up her grocery store and sell 'picaditas' and 'dobladitas'.  She hopes to use her loans to achieve this.  Her business has helped her financially.  The improvements she would like to make to her home are to put down flooring, buy some stools and remodel her water tank.  Her hopes are to grow her business and to put down flooring in her home.

Claudia is happy to be receiving this loan which she has been given so that her business can grow and become well known.   The members of the group would like to say to Kiva and Fundación Realidad "Many thanks for your help.  Please lower the interest rates so that we can manage and so that all is well.  Let's see if you can lower the interest rates and continue lending to us".

Jaloxtoc is a beautiful village.  From it, you can see the countryside and the hills.  People grow sorghum, corn and onions.

loans.use: To buy sausages, ham, yoghurt, cheese, Añejo cheese, Oaxaca cheese, soft drinks and paint to paint her house

loans.name: Surriya's Group

texts.en:
Surriya is 42 years old, and a mother of 2 daughters and a son. All of the children are young and stay at home. Surriya is unable to provide them with education facilities due to poor financial resources. She has lived in a 2 room brick house with her family in the area of Green town for many years.  Green town is located in Lahore, which is Pakistan’s second largest city and known for its history and culture.

Her husband’s name is M. I. and he sells traditional Punjabi food called Samosay and Pakorey (which are spicy foods made up of potatoes and different spices). Surriya has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for further improvement of her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy required items like spices and potatoes in bulk quantity to make larger quantities of Samosas and Pakodas to sell. He will also buy some plastic chairs and tables to increase the sitting arrangements at his business place. He has been running this business for past 10 years and Surriya is confident that a loan investment will bring even more profits to him. 

She is a new loan applicant. She hopes it will bring good changes to her husband’s business.

loans.use: To buy required items for Punjabi food selling business.

loans.name: El Bocotito Group

texts.es:
Este grupo se llama el bocotito, esta ubicado en el municipio de Florencio Villareal guerrero, los integrantes del grupo decidieron ponerle este nombre puesto que en su comunidad se da una madera que lleva este nombre, es por eso que así decidieron nombrar a su grupo, esta historia es acerca de la señora clara O. A., ya que es una de las integrantes de este grupo, cuenta con 30 años de edad, es casada, tiene 2 hijos, angélica de 11 años y Abel de 9 años de edad de los cuales los 2 estudian la mayor esta cursando el sexto año de primaria y el menor esta en cuarto año, ella se dedica a la venta de antojitos mexicanos.

Doña clara se decidió por este negocio, ya que dice tiene mucha demanda y deja muy buenas ganancias, aparte de que quería buscar la forma de mejorar su calidad de vida y la de su familia, también para darles una muy buena educación de sus hijos, ella invirtió su crédito en la compra de mas insumos como son: sal, aceite, jitomates, variedad de chiles, cebollas, maíz, y demás especies que utiliza, para así tener una mejor producción y mas variedad de productos, y así mismo incrementar un poco mas sus ventas.
 
Ella dice que le esta yendo súper bien con su negocio, tanto que esta empezando a ahorrar parte de las ganancias obtenidas de su negocio, para terminar de construir la cocina para su casa y para seguir apoyando a sus hijos con sus estudios para que tengan una muy buena carrera profesional, también sigue invirtiendo en su negocio. 

Comenta que su negocio ésta beneficiando mucho a los vecinos de su colonia, ya que no hay muchas personas que se dediquen a esta actividad ahí cerca, así que como es la única que vende ahí y esta mas cerca, todos le compran a ella, aparte de la excelente atención y servicio que les brinda a sus clientes. 

El sueño que tiene doña clara es el de construir un local, ahí mismo en su casa para ampliar un poco mas su negocio, ya que lo que en verdad quiere es poner una fondita, para así tenerla mucho mas surtida, para obtener mas y mejores ingresos y así poder continuar apoyando a sus hijos con sus estudios superiores, para que tengan una muy buena profesión.

Nos dice que los integrantes de su grupo, son personas muy responsables y pagadoras ya que tienen tiempo de conocerse y se llevan muy bien, aparte de que son de la misma comunidad, es por eso que en ninguna ocasión se han atrasado o dejado de pagar su crédito, ya que no quieren defraudar la confianza que la empresa ha depositado en ellos.

Ella esta muy agradecida con fundación realidad y kiva por el apoyo del préstamo que le otorgaron ya que gracias a esto su negocio esta mejorando mucho y su vida y la de su familia también esta cambiando.
Los integrantes de el bocotito y las actividades a las que se dedican son las siguientes: 
María B. S.-venta de pescados
Lucero B. R.-venta de ropa
Flor yesenia S. O.-venta de calzado
María estela J. V.-venta de quesos
Octavia P. C.-venta de dulces
Ángel R. L.-compra de ganado
Fortunata M. M.-venta de calzado
Candido S. B.-carpintería
Clara O. A.-antojitos
Pragedis S. R.-venta de pescados
Margarita N. S.-venta de pescados
texts.en:
This group is called “El Bocotito” and is located in the town of Florencio Villareal, in the state of Guerrero.  The members decided to name the group for a local wood of the same name.  Here's the story of Clara O. A., one member of the group. She's 30-years-old, and married with two children, Angélica, 11, and Abel, 9, both in school.  The eldest is in sixth grade and the youngest is in fourth.  Clara earns her living selling Mexican finger-foods.

She decided on this business because there's high demand and good profits, in addition to the fact that she was looking for a way to improve the quality of life for herself and her family and provide a really good education for her kids.  She invested her loan in more ingredients, including: chiles, onions, corn, etc., so she could increase production and offer a wider variety of products in order to increase sales a bit.
 
Clara says business is going super-well, so well that she's starting to save up part of her profits to finish building the kitchen in her house, to keep supporting the kids' education so they can have really good professional careers, and to continue investing in her business. 

Clara says that her business has benefited quite a bit from the locals in her town, because there aren't many people in the same business nearby.  Everyone buys from her because she's the only one, she's close by, and she offers excellent attention and service to her clientele.

Clara's dream is to build a shop, right in her house, so she can expand her business a little.  What she really wants is to put in a little restaurant so she can stock more items, bring in more income, and continue supporting the kids' higher education so they'll have really good professions.

Clara tells us the members of her group are very responsible people who make their payments. They've had time to get to know each other and they get along very well; plus, they're from the same community so they've never been late or failed to pay their loans off, because they don't want to destroy the trust the organization has placed in them.

Clara really appreciates Fundación Realidad and Kiva for supporting them with loans; thanks to that, her business is really improving and her and her family's lives are changing.

The members of the “El Bocotito” group and their businesses are: 

María B. S. sells fish
Lucero B. R. sells clothing
Flor Yesenia S. O. sells footwear
María Estela J. V. sells cheese
Octavia P. C. sells candy
Ángel R. L. buys cattle
Fortunata M. M. sells footwear
Candido S. B. is a carpenter
Clara O. A. sells finger-foods
Pragedis S. R. sells fish
Margarita N. S. sells fish

loans.use: She invested her loan in more ingredients like salt, oil, tomatoes, different kinds of chiles, onions, corn, and other ingredients she uses.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To repair his house to live comfortably.

loans.name: Chequita

texts.en:
Chequita D. is from the village of Binuangan, Misamis Oriental. She is 63 years old. Chequita is widowed and has 1 adult child. To make a living, Chequita owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, junk foods & toothpaste in the local community. Chequita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Chequita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Chequita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and working capital. Chequita is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like junk foods & canned goods. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Chequita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell like junk foods & canned goods.

loans.name: Las Animas Group

texts.es:
Este grupo lleva por nombre las  animas, esta ubicado en el municipio de Tecoanapa guerrero, los integrantes del grupo decidieron ponerle este nombre por que así se llama la comunidad donde viven y la mayoría de los integrantes pertenecen a esta comunidad, es por eso que decidieron ponerle así , esta historia es acerca de la señora Maribel C. L., ya que ella es la representante de este grupo, cuenta con 38 años de edad, esta casada y tienen 4 hijos Alejandra, Eduardo, estefan y luceli, de los cuales  los cuatro estudian, la mayor esta cursando el primer año de prepa, el otro esta en segundo año de secundaria y dos mas están en cuarto y sexto año de primaria, ella se dedica a la venta de cosméticos por catalogo.

Doña Maribel decidió iniciar con este negocio por que tenia la necesidad de mejorar su calidad de vida y la de su familia, y sacar a sus hijos adelante, ya que no tenia la solvencia económica suficiente para conseguir darles una mejor educación a sus hijos y apoyar a su esposo con los gastos de la casa, el crédito que recibió lo invirtió en la compra de mas mercancía y catálogos como son: labiales, rubores, sombras, delineadores y mascaras, para continuar con las ventas de su negocio.

Dice que su negocio le esta beneficiando bastante ya que de las ganancias obtenidas esta sacando para pagar los estudios de sus hijos y mejorar su calidad de vida, también ahora esta mejorando su solvencia económica, tanto que esta ahorrando para comprarse una estufa, ya que la que tiene esta muy vieja. 

La señora Maribel desea seguir invirtiendo en su negocio para poder hacerlo crecer mucho mas, ya que quiere construir un local un poco mas grande, para ampliar su negocio, puesto que quiere poner su tienda de productos de belleza, para así tener mas variedad de productos e incrementar y mejorar sus ingresos, para así poder seguir apoyando a sus hijos con sus estudios, para que pueda seguir estudiando y tengan una muy buena carrera profesional, y puedan tener un mejor futuro.

Dice que todos sus compañeros, son personas responsables y pagadoras puesto que todas se conocen ya que son de la misma comunidad puesto que también son muy amigos así que no tienen ningún problema entre ellos, y hasta ahora nadie ha fallado con los pagos del crédito, ya que son muy responsables, puntuales y trabajadores.

Ella esta muy agradecida con los prestatarios de kiva y con FRAC, ya que gracias a ellos esta saliendo adelante y ha podido tener su propio negocio, para así seguir apoyando a su familia para tener una mejor calidad de vida.
Las personas que integran el grupo de las animas y las actividades en las que invirtieron su crédito son las siguientes:
María victoria
texts.en:
The name of this group is Las Animas. The members live in the municipality of Tecoanapa Guerrero and decided on this name for the group because it is the name of the community where the majority of the members live.

Señora Maribel C. L. is the representative of the group and this is her story. She is 38 years old, married, and has four children: Alejandra, Eduardo, Estefan, and Luceli. They all attend school; the eldest is in first year college, the second in second year of high school, the last two are in the fourth and sixth year of primary school. Maribel’s job is selling cosmetics from a catalog.

She decided to start this business because she needed to provide a better standard of living for herself and her family and to help her children get ahead. As she could not afford to educate her children well nor assist her husband with household expenses, she took on a loan to buy catalogs and more merchandise such as lipstick, blush, eyeshadow, eyeliner, and mascara to start the business.

She says that the business has helped her a lot and she now can pay for her children’s studies and improve their quality of life. The money she earns has improved the family’s financial situation and she is now saving to buy a stove since the one that she has is very old.

Sra. Maribel wishes to invest more money in her business so that it can expand much more. For that reason she wants to build a bigger store from which to sell her beauty products. She will be able to have a greater variety and thus increase sales and income. Then she can continue helping her children through school so they can get good jobs and have a better future.

Maribel says that all the members of the group are responsible people who pay back their loans. They all know each other since they’re from the same community and they are all friends so there are no problems between them. Up to now no one has failed to make their repayments as they are responsible, punctual and hardworking.


The members of the Las Animas group and the business in which they will invest their loan:
María Victoria Angel B.-selling sandals 
Rafaela G. H.-fruit seller
Gregoria B. N.-selling chickens 
Maribel C. L.-selling cosmetics 
Petra S. C.-selling fish
 María de Jesús G. N.-selling snacks
 Gregoria Salome A. J.- selling snacks
 Evangelista C. C.-fruit seller
 Marena B. A.-selling cosmetics
 Leonarda R. G.-fruit seller 
María C. M.-fruit seller 
María Félix C. R.-fishmonger

loans.use: to buy more beauty products for her business

loans.name: Generosa

texts.en:
Generosa M. is 68 years old, married, and has three children.  She lives in the town of Tagbilaran. Generosa has a small sari-sari store where she sells chorizo and other products. She also raises pigs in her backyard. She fattens the pigs and sells them in the market. Generosa does her best to improve her business.

Generosa joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Generosa has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Generosa is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase pig feed and additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her family financially.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed and additional products to sell

loans.name: Luzonia

texts.en:
Luzonia C. is from the village of Malagana, Claveria, Misamis Oriental. She is 49 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Luzonia owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods, and toothpaste in the local community. Luzonia has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 11,000 PHP a month. 

In 2010, Luzonia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Luzonia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to purchase additional inventory and acquire working capital. Luzonia is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell such as canned goods and snack foods. This will be Luzonia's fourth loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products such as canned goods and snack food to sell

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca P., 54 years old, is married and lives in Tuyabang Proper, Oroqueita City, Misamis Occidental. She has three children. Rebecca has sold ornamental flowers for ten years. She sells her flowers on the street in Ozamis City.

Rebecca joined Paglaum Multi-purpose Co-operative to access funds for her business. She has successfully repaid all her previous loan obligations and today, she applies for 8,000 PHP for additional working capital. 

Rebecca's dream is to own a little parcel of land for her ornamental flower plantation.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora S. is from the city of Dapitan. She is 54 years old and widowed with four adult children.

Leonora has a business planting and harvesting corn for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns an average of approximately 1,750 PHP a month. She also raises pigs in her back yard.

In 2007, Leonora joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC and is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional piglets and feed. This loan will be her seventh from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase piglets and feed

loans.name: Los Jimenes Group

texts.es:
Este grupo se llama los Jimenez, esta ubicado en Ayutla guerrero, decidieron ponerle este nombre por que así se llama la calle por donde viven, ya que todos los integrantes viven sobre esa misma calle la  historia es acerca de la señora Rosalía G. C., ya que es una de las integrantes que conforman este grupo, cuenta con 30 años de edad, es madre soltera, tiene tres hijos de los cuales solo dos estudian, el mayor esta en sexto de primaria y el otro en cuarto año, ya que el menor apenas tiene 2 años, ella tiene una tienda de abarrotes, con la cual lleva mas de 5 años.

Ella eligió esta negocio, ya que quería buscar la manera de apoyar a sus hijos y sacarlos adelante, y así mismo tener una mejor solvencia económica, para mejor su calidad de vida, ya que no contaba con el apoyo de nadie, aparte de que dice es una muy buena fuente de ingresos, es por eso que decidió empezar con este negocio, con el préstamo que recibió va a continuar invirtiendo en su tienda, en la compra de mas mercancía como son: refrescos, aguas, aceite, huevos, sal, azúcar, jabón, papel higiénico y demás artículos, para continuar con sus ventas.

Su negocio le esta sirviendo de mucho, ya que de las ganancias obtenidas, esta sacando para continuar apoyando a sus hijos con sus estudios y con sus gastos personales e ir mejorando cada vez mas su calidad de vida, además de que esta ahorrando para comprarse una lavadora, ya que no cuenta con una y le hace mucha falta . 

Doña Rosalía dice que su meta  es la de hacer que su negocio crezca empresarialmente, ya que quiere construir un local más grande, puesto que lo que ella mas desea es convertir su pequeña tienda en una abarrotería, para de esta forma tenerla muy bien surtida y así obtener más y mejores ganancias.  

Ella dice que conoce muy bien a sus compañeros y nos comenta que son personas muy responsables, gente trabajadora, confiable que tienen ganas de salir adelante y superarse y por lo mismo en ninguna ocasión se han atrasado o fallado con los pagos de su crédito, ya que quieren seguir contando con el apoyo de mas prestamos.

Da las gracias a los prestatarios de kiva, por darle la oportunidad y confianza, pero sobre todo por creer en ella, puesto que gracias a su ayuda pudo invertir en su negocio y asi tener una mejor calidad de vida junto con su familia y un mejor futuro.

Los integrantes del grupo de los Jimenez y las actividades que realizan son las siguientes:
Antonia O. C.-antojitos
Eva luz bolívar R.-venta de calzado
Cristina H. Márquez-venta de semillas
Teresa B. Z.- antojitos
Gudelia S. V.-venta de ropa
Delia yudith R. M.-accesorios para computadoras
Alma iris B. Z.- venta de cosméticos
José Alberto B. N.-venta de refrescos
Irving adalid M. O.-venta de comida
Rosalía G. C.-tienda de abarrotes
Bernardina G. V.-venta de zapatos
Mary carmen V. A.-venta de zapatos
texts.en:
This group, called “Los Jimenez,” is located in Ayutla, Guerrero, and decided on this name because it's the name of the street where they live. All the members live on the same street. One member, Rosalia, is 30 years old, a single mother with 3 children, 2 of whom are in school. The oldest is in 6th year of primary and the other is in 4th year. The youngest is just 2 years old. Rosalia has had a grocery store for 5 years.

She chose to open this business because she was looking for a means of supporting and advancing her children, and of solving economic problems, and improving her quality of life, since she couldn't count on help from anyone. Rosalia is requesting a loan to continue investing in her store, buying more merchandise such as soft drinks, water, cooking oil, eggs, salt, sugar, soap, toilet paper, and other articles, to continue her sales.

Rosalia's business is serving her well. From the earnings, she is able to continue helping her children with their studies, and cover personal expenses, and to continue improving her quality of life. She is also saving to buy a washing machine, which she lacks and really needs.

Rosalia says that her goal is to make her business grow as an enterprise. She wants to build a larger store. What she most desires is to convert her small store into a real grocery, and to have it well stocked and, thus, to obtain more and better earnings.

Rosalia says she knows her fellow members very well and she comments that they are very responsible and hard-working people, and she is confident that they have the urge to get ahead and overcome, and for that reason, in no occasion have they fallen behind in their loan payments, since they want to continue counting on the help of more loans.

She thanks Kiva investors for providing this opportunity and having confidence, but above all, for believing in her, since thanks to their help, she can invest in her business and, thus, enjoy a better quality of life together with her family, and a better future.

The members of the Los Jimenez Group and their activities are as follows:
Antonia O. C. – snack sales
Eva Luz Bolívar R. - shoe sales
Cristina H. Márquez – seed sales
Teresa B. Z. – snack sales
Gudelia S. V. – clothing sales
Delia Judith R. M. – computer accessories
Alma Iris B. Z. – cosmetic sales
José Alberto B. N. – soft drink sales
Irving Adalid M. O. – meal sales
Rosalía G. C. – grocery store
Bernardina G. V. – shoe sales
Mary Carmen V. A. – shoe sales

loans.use: TO BUY MERCHANDISE LIKE SOFT DRINKS, WATER, OIL, EGGS, SALT, SUGAR, SOAP, TOILET PAPER, AND OTHER ITEMS

loans.name: Irenea

texts.en:
Irenea A. is from the village of Lagag. She is 60 years old and married. To make a living, Irenea sells rice, corn and other vegetables that she plants. She also raises pigs.

In 2008, Irenea joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Irenea is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to buy additional pigs. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Irenea from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Buy additional pigs to raise.

loans.name: Jazmin Group

texts.es: Este grupo solidario se llama Jazmín se encuentra localizado en la comunidad de Barrio San Pedro, Acteopan, en el estado de Puebla, México, está conformado por 5 integrantes mujeres que se conocen y son vecinas ellas son la señora Petra A. M. va a comprar con su crédito barro, leña, greta, para la elaboración de cazuelas y jarros y los vende crudos, la señora Jorgina B. T. va a comprar barro, leña, pintura para elaboración de cazuelas, la señora Margarita M. V. va a comprar leña, barro greta para elaborar sus cazuelas y en día de muertos elabora los jarros, la señora María Myriam Guzmán C.  va a comprar azúcar por bulto, aceite por caja, dulces, jugos por caja para surtir su negocio de venta de tortas, picaditas, dobladitas, la señora Irene C. Arriza va a comprar ollas, cazuelas para surtir su negocio,  va a comprar greta, leña, pintura, barro para elaborar sus cazuelas y ollas chicas y grandes. La señora María Myriam es integrante del grupo ella tiene 22 años de edad estudio hasta el bachillerato tiene su certificado, ella es casada, no tiene hijos, ella tiene su negocio de venta de comida en la Telesecundaria a y solicito su préstamo para comprar aceite, arroz, azúcar, dulces, refrescos y las verduras jitomates, tomates, lechuga, queso, crema y también va a arreglar su baño hacerlo de block porque el que tiene es de carrizo, sus clientes son los estudiantes, los maestro, padres de familia y les ofrece a sus clientes tacos, tostadas, quesadillas, tortas, dulces y refrescos, su negocio lo inicio hace 3 años, por necesidad aprendió viendo como los preparaban , su mama le enseño a preparar la comida, a ella le dijeron que si quería vender el comité de padres de familia como no había nadie quien vendiera a ella le dijeron y le gusto, su suegro le presto para iniciar con la venta , llega a su negocio caminando transporta su mercancía en carretilla, su negocio es importante y especial porque de ahí come, lo que más le gusta de su negocio es cuando vende cuando los muchachos compran sus alimentos y no se alejan, los desafíos que enfrenta su negocio es el clima en temporal cuando llueve casi no llevan dinero los muchachos, bajan las ventas, la competencia que enfrenta el negocio es que hay una señora que vende los mismos productos en la escuela, las ganancias del negocio las utiliza para ir a comprar a la central cada ocho días los insumos para elaborar su comida, para pagar el préstamo, y para pagar su cuota por ir a vender a la telesecundaria, su esposo le va ayuda en la venta de los alimentos en todo le ayuda él sabe hacer de todo. San Marcos es bonito se respira aire puro, se celebra las fiestas del patrón San Marcos el 25 de Abril hay misas, procesión, baile, juegos mecánicos, brinco de chínelos, siembran de temporal maíz y sorgo, casi todos trabajan la alfarería. Este negocio le ha ayudado mucho a su familia en la alimentación, los planes y esperanzas son seguir en el negocio de las ventas de alimentos para que tenga ganancias para comprar un carro para ir a comprar la mercancía y para trasladarse de su casa a la escuela con los alimentos, la señora María Miriam está Feliz con este préstamo porque va a poder seguir adelante con su negocio. Las integrantes del grupo quiere decirles a Kiva y a Fundación Realidad “gracias por el apoyo y por la confianza que nos dan, gracias porque con estos créditos salimos adelante con nuestros negocios y nuestras familias”.
texts.en:
This communal group called Jazmín is located in the community of Barrio San Pedro, Acteopan, in the state of Puebla, Mexico. It is made up of 5 women who are neighbors and know each other well. 

Ms. Petra A. M. is going to use her loan to buy clay, wood and glaze for the manufacture of pots and jars and she also sells unglazed pots. 

Ms. Jorgina B. T. is going to buy clay, wood and paints for making pots. 

Ms. Margarita M. V. is going to buy wood, clay, and glaze to make pots and jars for the Day of the Dead. 

Ms. María Myriam Guzmán C. is going to buy bags of sugar, boxed oil, sweets and boxed juices to stock her business selling cakes, picaditas and dobladitas (various traditional fast food items).

Ms. Irene C. Arriza is going to buy pots and pans to stock her business. She is going to buy glaze, wood, paint, and clay to manufacture large and small pots and pans. 

María Myriam is a member of the group. She is 22 years old and she has her high school diploma. She is married and does not have any children. She has a business selling food in the telesecundaria (a distance school program for secondary and high school students). She is requesting a loan to buy oil, rice, sugar, sweets, soft drinks, vegetables, tomatoes, lettuce, cheese, and cream. She is also going to fix her bathroom and construct it using brick rather than bamboo. Her customers are students, teachers, parents and she offers them tacos, tostadas, quesadillas, tortas, sweets and soft drinks. She started her business 3 years ago out of necessity and learned by watching others prepare. Her mother taught her to prepare food, and the parent committee at the school told her that since there wasn't anyone to sell food at school if she wanted to do so she could and she liked the idea. Her father-in-law lent her the money to start sales. She walks to work, carrying her goods in a wheelbarrow. Her business is important and special to her because she eats there. What she likes most about her job is when she sells, when the boys buy her foods and do not walk away. The greatest challenge she faces is the weather, when it rains, or when the boys do not bring money because sales decrease. Her competition is a lady who sells the same products in the school. She uses her business profits to go shopping in the center every eight days for food supplies, to stock her food supply, repay the loan, and to pay her dues from selling to the telesecundaria. Her husband helps with overall food sales and he knows how to do everything. 

San Marcos is a nice place to breathe fresh air. They celebrate the patron saint of San Marcos on April 25. There are masses, procession, dances, carnival rides, Brinco de Chinelos (traditional indigenous dance from the state of Morelos), the planting of corn and sorghum, and almost all do pottery work. 

This business has helped in feeding their family. The plans and hopes are to continue with the business selling food to make earnings to buy a car to use to go and buy the merchandise and to travel from their house to the school with their food. 

Ms. María Miriam is happy with this loan because she is able to continue growing her business. The members of the this group want to tell Kiva and the Fundación Realidad "Thank you for the support and the trust you give us, thanks to these loans we can get ahead in our business and our families".

loans.use: Purchase packages of sugar, boxed oil, rice, sweets, juices, soft drinks, vegetables, green and red tomatoes, chiles, cheese, cream

location.town: Barrio San Pedro, Acteopan, Estado de Puebla

loans.name: Lucila

texts.en:
Lucila C. is from the village of Malagana, Claveria, Misamis Oriental. She is 40 years old, separated and has eight school-aged children. To make a living, Lucila buys and sells green and yellow bananas. Lucila has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Lucila joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12000 PHP from HSPFI and is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional bananas to sell. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Lucila from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand the her business. 

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase products like green bananas to sell

loans.name: Irma

texts.en:
Irma T. is from the village of Upper Dicayas. She is 33 years old and married with four school-aged children. 

Irma owns a barbecue food stall. She has been engaged in her business for over 8 months and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Irma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,900 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional raw materials for her barbecue business.

Irma is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used to purchase materials for house repair. This loan will be her 5th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase materials for house repair

loans.name: Nelia

texts.en: Mrs. Nelia C. has enjoyed more than five years of association with Paglaum Multi Purpose Cooperative, a partner through thick and thin for her business. Her primary source of income is buying & selling coconuts. It’s a daily challenge for her to submit her loan payments on time, but this has now become a habit. Nelia is 58 years old, married, and has three children. She tells us with pride that she is able to nurture all her children well. Finishing a degree was far out of sight for her, but she’s happy that she was able to send her children to school. She has applied to Paglaum MPC for a loan of PHP 14,900 for additional working capital for her coconut buy & sell business.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Monte Verde Group

texts.es:
El grupo se llama Monte Verde y se ubica en la localidad de Benito Juárez Municipio de Copainala Estado de Chiapas México, se integra de cinco señoras  quien cada una se dedica a diferente actividad.

         La señora Blanca Adali M. Santo, es casada con el señor  José Verneden García V. y tiene una hija de nombre Dayli Rubí de tres años, ella invierte el préstamo e la compra de productos por catálogos  de la marca avon, en donde lleva  un año y once meses   y comenta que le va bien ya que  ha tenido buenos ingresos en su hogar.

         Inicio con esta actividad ya que la invitaron unas compañeras porque a ellas les daba buen resultado y fue como se animo a realizarlo,  hora ve que si es cierto lo que la habían dicho pues está logrando obtener buenos ingresos en su trabajo y hogar.

         De las ganancia que va  obteniendo lo invierte en la misma actividad y así  se valla incrementado día a con día y logre salir adelante con la ayuda de su esposo que también la poya aportando para que sea de manera puntual en sus pagos.

        Lo que ella desea  es que su con el tiempo logre tener más grande su negocio y con ello poder ahorrar y obtener mejores ingresos en su familia, que para ella  es lo más importante.

        Las personas que integran en el grupo san las siguientes:
Flor de Luz Vázquez Sánchez:   invierte el préstamo en la compra de ropas para luego venderlo en la misma localidad.

        María Celinda García Hernández: invierte el préstamo en la compra de mercancía para surtir su tienda de abarrotes.

        Victoria V. López:   invierte el préstamo en la  compra de pollos de rancho  para luego venderlo en la misma comunidad.

        Blanca Adali M. S.: invierte el préstamo en la compra de productos por cátalos de la marca avon.
    
        Guadalupe López García: invertirá el préstamo en la compra de  materiales para elaborar vestidos, blusas y faldas.
texts.en:
This group is called Monte Verde and is located in Benito Juárez, the municipal of Copainala in the state of Chiapas, Mexico. This group has 5 members, each one dedicated to a different activity. 

Mrs. Blanca Adali M. Santo is married to Mr. José Verneden García V. and has one 3 year-old daughter named Dayli Rubí. She is using the loan to buy catalog products from Avon. She has been doing this for one year and eleven months and says that she is doing well and earns a great income at home. 
         
She started this business and since has invited others to participate because she has gotten great results and her achievements are encouraging. Now she sees that if it's true what they said, she will make a good income in her work and home.

The money earned is invested in the business, thus increasing day after day and continues to grow with the help of her husband who also supports her, providing a way to make her payments.
         
She wants to have the time to grow her business and with it she would be able obtain a better income and save more money for her family, which for her is the most important thing. 
        
The following people make up this group:

        Flor de Luz Vázquez Sánchez:   using the loan to buy clothing to then sell in the area.

        María Celinda García Hernández: using the loan to buy merchandise to stock her grocery store.

        Victoria V. López: using the loan to buy chicken to sell in the community.

        Blanca Adali M. S.: using the loan to buy products from the Avon catalog.
    
        Guadalupe López García: using the loan to buy materials to make dresses, blouses and skirts.

loans.use:
la compra de productos  de lamarca  avon, como son: perfumes, laviales, desodorantes, entre otros.

Purchase of Avon Products such as: Perfumes, Lipsticks, Deodorants, among others.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Mrs. Helen H., 49, lives in Talairon, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental where she and her husband, a farmer, have two children. In order to help her husband while at home, she decided to raise pigs for an additional source of income. 

Helen became a micro entrepreneur because of Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative in 2005. This co-op teaches women how to develop their own businesses to support their spouses’ incomes. She has thus far been able to obtain several loans and now is requesting PHP 10,000 to buy feed and piglets. Her husband is very supportive of her endeavors.

She dreams of having a piggery someday with complete facilities.

loans.use: To buy feed and piglets

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita L. is from the village of Claveria, Misamis Oriental. She is 49 years old. Teresita is widowed and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Teresita owns & operates a business making and selling snacks & other Filipino delicacies like biko, suman, puto, bingka & assorted soft drinks in the local community. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Teresita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale like sugar & flour. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Teresita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients like sugar & flour

loans.name: El Manguito Group

texts.es:
Señora María Dora Gonzales Pérez, vive en la localidad de Benito Juárez, Municipio de Copainala Estado de Chiapas México. Es cada con el señor   Sergio Zea González con quien procreo dos hijos y son: Blanca Imelda de veinti un años de edad, el otro es Felipe Javier de diesi nueve años.

       Ella es la primera vez que solicita  un préstamo y es para invertirlo en la cosecha de café ya que tiene que pagar personal paraqué se lo trasladen a su casa cuando es la cosecha, comenta  que esta actividad es muy buena ya que le deja buenos ingresos dentro de su familia.

      Lo que lo inspiro a realizar este trabajo es que desde que muy   joven sus padres le enseñaron atrabajar con la cosecha  de café y cuando se caso le dieron un pequeño cafetal de la cual pueda disponer y gracias adiós lleva  veinticinco años con su rancho que la apoya en todo.

     De la ganancia que obtiene de cada venta lo invierte en la misma actividad para mandar a limpiar su cafetal, para que cuando venga la cosecha este limpio y  así su personal pueda trabajar a gusto.

     Lo que ella desea es que logre seguir trabajando hasta que Dios le preste vida y así darle lo mejor a sus hijos para que terminen una profesión.

    María Dora se integro al grupo una invitación que le hizo la señora máxima a que se uniera a su grupo para solicitar un préstamo,  en donde ella también pueda trabajar. Su grupo se llama el manguito la razón del nombre es por que donde de hace la reunión ay un árbol de mango.

      Las personas que integran el grupo son las siguientes:

    Máxima Pérez Sánchez: compra de ganado para pie de cría, como también la engorda de marrano para después venderlo.

    María del Rosario C. A.: invierte el préstamo en la compra de marranos  para engordarlo y liego venderlo por quilo, como también la venta de pollos de rancho.

    María Dora González Pérez: invertirá el préstamo en la compra y venta de productos garigolas, como es el café.
texts.en:
Mrs. María Dora Gonzales Pérez lives in Benito Juárez, in the Municipal of Copainala and state of Chiapas, Mexico. 

She is married to Mr. Sergio Zea González with whom she has two children: Blanca Imelda, 21 years old, Felipe Javier, 19 years old.

This is her first loan and she is using it to invest in the coffee harvest. She has to pay staff so that they can transfer the crop to her house when it is harvested. She says that this activity is very good as it brings in a good income for their family.

What inspires her to do this work is from a very young age her parents taught her to harvest coffee and when she married they gave her a small coffee plantation of her own. She thanks God for this ranch because it has fully supported her for 25 years.

The profit she makes from each sale is invested in this work, to clean her plantation, so that when the harvest comes in it is clean and the staff can work comfortably.

She wants to continue working as long as God gives her life, so that she can provide the best for her children and they finish a career. 

María Dora was invited to join this group by Mrs. Máxima, who brings this group together to request loans, so she can also work. Her group is called "el manguito" (mango) because they all meet by a mango tree. 

The following people make up this group:

    Máxima Pérez Sánchez: using the loan to purchase cattle for breeding, as well as fattening pigs and then selling them.

    María del Rosario C. A.: using the loan to buy pigs to fatten and then sell by the kilo, as well as sell chicken.

    María Dora González Pérez: using the loan to purchase and sell agricultural products, such as coffee.

loans.use: Staff working at the ranch harvesting coffee to then sell.

loans.name: Cecelia

texts.en:
Cecelia Y. is from the village of Upper Dicayas. She is 58 years old. Cecelia is married and has four adult children. To make a living, Cecelia owns & operates a specialized retail store selling coconut wine known as "tuba" in the local community. Cecelia has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2005, Cecelia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cecelia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,900 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. Cecelia is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP, which will be used to purchase (tuba) and make her motorcycle monthly payment. This will be the 11th loan taken out by Cecelia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchase native wine (tuba) and make motorcycle payments

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth M. is from the village of Lagonglong, Misamis Oriental. She is 51 years old. Elizabeth is separated from her spouse and has five adult-aged children. To make a living, Elizabeth owns & operates a business buying and selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. Elizabeth has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2001, Elizabeth joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elizabeth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Elizabeth is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell, like milkfish and sardines. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Elizabeth from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish to sell

loans.name: Genelita

texts.en:
