Genelita A. is 44 years old, married and has two school-aged children. She is from the village of Cawa-Cawa, a part of Dapitan City, Zamboanga del Norte province on the Mindanao islands. Genelita runs a general store from which she sells a variety of different products to the local community. She has been in business for over eight years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Genelita joined PMPC to gain access to its financial services. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from PMPC that was used to purchase materials for her store’s renovation. Genelita is requesting a new loan, her sixth from PMPC, of 7,000 PHP that will be used to purchase an additional variety of products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her family’s living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell in her store

loans.name: Xochicalco Group

texts.es: Este grupo solidario se llama Xochicalco, se encuentra localizado en la comunidad de Tétela del Volcán, en el estado de Morelos, México, está conformado por 4 integrantes mujeres que se conocen y son vecinas, las integrantes son la señora Fabiola Rodríguez A. va a comprar con su crédito catálogos de temporada y a surtir algunos pedidos de zapatos para caballero, dama y niño, la señora Valentina M. Jiménez va a comprar zapatos va a surtir sus pedidos, la señora Ma Anselma M. P. va a comprar semillas como frijol, maíz, pasilla, juagillo, lentejas, para surtir su negocio, la señora María de Lourdes V. C. va a comprar frijol, maíz, jabón, aceite, sopas, rollos de papel higiénico para surtir su negocio. La señora Fabiola Rodríguez A. tiene 33 años de edad, estudio hasta el 3er. año de preparatoria, ella es casada y tiene 3 hijos Johan de 6 años de edad estudia la primaria, Pamela de 4 años de edad está en preescolar, Marco Antonio tiene 2 años, la señora Fabiola tiene su negocio de venta de zapato por catalogo venta de elotes preparados y chicharrones preparados y solicito su préstamo para comprar zapatos de caballero, de dama y de niños para surtir sus pedidos, este negocio lo inicio hace 4 años su cuñada la invito le dijo que vendiera zapatos y ella fue a Cuautla a comprar sus catálogos para iniciar sus ventas por catalogo, su esposo estaba en los Estados Unidos trabajando y le mando para comprar sus catálogos y los zapatos, su negocio es ambulante va caminando ofreciendo los productos, su negocio es importante por la ventaja de que sale cuando puede salir en sus tiempos libres y no descuida a sus niños, la parte favorita de su negocio es cuando sale a vender los zapatos sale y se distrae, sus clientes son sus vecinos, familiares, muchachas, los desafíos que enfrenta su negocio es el clima cuando esta lluvioso no puede salir a vender, las ganancias del negocio las invierte para seguir comprando zapatos, ella está planeando ampliar su negocio está metiendo mas catálogos de otras marcas de zapatos y lo piensa logar con los catálogos y saliendo a vender. Tétela del Volcán es bonito por sus paisajes, su clima frio, hay muchos cerros, muchos árboles y mucha vegetación se dan los duraznos, el aguacate, mísperos, ciruela, granada, también siembran frijol, maíz. su negocio ha ayudado a su familia en lo económico, para la escuela de sus hijos, las mejorías que desea hacer a su vivienda son repellar su casa y comprar las puertas, sus planes y esperanzas son implementar más productos y poner una zapatería, mostrando los catálogos,  la señora Fabiola está emocionada con el préstamo que le van a dar porque va a poder comprar sus catalogas nuevos de temporada y va a surtir sus pedidos, las mejorías que desea lograr para el futuro de su hijos es poder seguir dándoles estudios a sus hijos y lo piensa lograr seguir vendiendo sus zapatos. Las integrantes del grupo quieren decirle a Kiva y a Fundación Realidad “les agradecemos la oportunidad que nos dan, gracias a ustedes vamos a poder tener este apoyo para que crezcan nuestros negocio”.
texts.en:
This communal bank is called Xochicalco.  It is located in the Tétela del Volcán community in the state of Morelos, Mexico.  It is made up of 4 female members that know each other and are neighbors.  Members Señora Fabiola Rodríguez A. and Señora Valentina M. Jiménez are going to use the loan to purchase men's, women's and children's footwear out of seasonal catalogs to fill orders. Señora Ma Anselma M. P. is going to purchase seeds such as beans, corn, pasilla, guagillo and lentils to stock her business.   Señora María de Lourdes V. C. is going to buy beans, corn, soap, oil, soups and toilet paper to stock her business.

Señora Fabiola Rodríguez A. is 33 years old and studied until her 3rd year of high school.  She is married and has 3 children, Johan, 6, attends elementary school, Pamela, 4, is in preschool and Marco Antonio is 2.  Señora Fabiola has a business selling footwear from catalogs, prepared elotes [Mexican corn on the cob] and prepared chicharrones [fried pork rinds].  She is requesting a loan to purchase men's, women's and children's footwear to fill her orders.  She started this business 4 years ago when her sister-in-law invited her and assured her that she would sell shoes.  She then went to Cuautla to purchase catalogs and shoes with the money that her husband sent from his earnings working in the United States.  She does business on an itinerant basis, walking around selling her products.  This business offers the advantage of letting her work in her free time and not have to worry about care for her children.  She enjoys selling footwear as her customers are her neighbors, family members and girls.  The weather presents a disadvantage of this business because when it rains she can't go out and sell.  She uses her earning to purchase more shoes.  She is planning to expand her business by carrying other brands of shoes.  

Tétela del Volcán is beautiful because of its scenery and its cool climate.  It is hilly with lots of trees and abundant vegetation.  Peaches, avocado, loquat, plums and pomegranate grow here.  They also plant beans and corn.   Her business has helped her family economically by supporting her children's education.  She wants to make improvements to her house and buy doors.  Her plans and hopes are to have more products and open a shoe store, displaying the catalogs.  Señora Fabiola is excited about the loan because she will be able to buy new seasonal catalogs and fill her orders.  Her goals are to continue supporting her children's education and to keep selling footwear.  

The members of the group want to tell Kiva and Fundación Realidad "we are grateful for the opportunity that you are offering us.  Thanks to your support we will be able to grow our businesses."

loans.use: To purchase men's, women's and children's footwear

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda A. is 30 years old, married and has three adult-aged children. She is from the village of Jasaan, Misamis Oriental province on the Mindanao islands. Erlinda runs a sari-sari (variety) shop from which she sells daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snacks and toothpaste to the local community. She has been in business for over five years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2005, Erlinda joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. Erlinda is requesting a new loan, her fourth from HSPFI, of 5,000 PHP that will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods and snacks. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

Hagdan sa Pag-uswag Foundation, Inc., or HSPFI, is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Bernard Mwaura

texts.en:
Bernard has been in the motorcycle business for the last two years in Naivasha town.  He is 31 years old, married to Margaret Njeri, and they have two children.

He heard about KADET through the awareness campaigns organised by the company.  This will be his third loan.  He repaid the previous loans well and in good time.  He plans to use this loan amount to buy a new motorcycle.

In future, Bernard hopes to grow in the transport industry and buy his own minibus to use for transportation.

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda M. is from the village of Kimaya, Jasaan, Misamis Oriental. She is 41 years old. Yolanda is married and has two adult-aged children. To make a living, Yolanda owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, junk food & toothpaste in the local community. Yolanda has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Yolanda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Yolanda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Yolanda is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & junk food. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Yolanda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.name: Cayetana

texts.en:
Cayetana, 57 years old, is from the town of Tagbilaran. She is married and has three children. To make a living, Cayetana owns & operates a business raising pigs for fattening and sale. 

Cayetana joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cayetana has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Cayetana is requesting a new loan of 18,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional piglets, feed and vitamins. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business.

Angelia is requesting a new loan, her fourth from HSPFI, of 12,000 PHP that will be used to purchase pig feed and other supplies. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business.

loans.name: Santiaguito Group

texts.es:
Grupo "Santiaguito" denominado así por que la comunidad en la que viven tiene el mismo nombre: Santiago Jicayan en el municipio de San Pedro Jicayan. A éste grupo está integrado por 10 mujeres humildes y de buenos sentimientos, todas son vecinas de esta localidad.
Todas se dedican comercio, la mayoria al bordado de servilletas y nahuas (vestidos),son mujeres muy trabajadoras y responsables.
La representante de este grupo se llama Lucia J. A. de 49 años de edad, esta casada con el señor Marcelino Garcia López quien tiene el oficio de policia, ellos tuvieron 8 hijos de los cuales tan solo 6 viven, ella estudio tan solo la primaria.
La señora Lucia solicita éste prestammo para comprar hilos para la elaboracion de servilletas, los hilos que utiliza son: hilo blanco, hilo de seda, dorsal, etc; además del bordado de servilletas ella vende pollo, así que otra parte del préstamo lo utilizá para comprar pollos.
La señora Lucia lleva 10 años realizando ésta actividad y aprendió a realizar los productos tomando un curso. Ella no tiene un local donde vender sus servilletas sino que sale a las comunidades cercanas a venderlas las servilletas que realiza, sus productos son de diferentes tamaños y varian su precio segun el tipo de hilo que utilizan y su tamaño, vende productos desde los 20 pesos hasta 200 pesos.
Anteriormente ella perteneció aun grupo que se llamó "Sangre India" en donde junto con otras mujeres elaboraban el tejido de las servilletas y había una persona que recolectaba sus productos y los vendian a nivel nacional,  pero conforme paso el tiempo el grupo se desintegró y cada quien vende sus productos.
Lucia con los ingresos que recibe de sus ventas lo invierte en un grupo musical que se llama "Santiago" en el cual su hijo el mas pequeño toca la bateria.
Su gran sueño de ella es que su trabajo sea reconocido mundialmente, que personas del extranjero compren sus productos, ya que con gran esfuerzo y dedicacion los realizan.
Ella se siente muy contenta por conseguir este prestamo y agradece a la fundacion por hacerles prestamos a personas como ellas.
Las mujeres que conforman este grupos son las siguientes:
Andrea M. A.: De 59 años de edad se dedica a la venta de Antojitos Regionales.
Carmen V. L.: De 41 años de edad se dedica  a la reposteria.
Cenorina L. X: De 40 años de edad se dedica a la compra de hilos para la elaboracion de servilletas.
Guadalupe J. X: De 41 años de edad se dedica a la venta de Antojitos Regionales.
Victoria J. L.: De 39 años de edad se dedic a a la compra de pollo para la venta.
Brigida J. A.: De 32 años de edad se dedica a la Alfareria.
Florentina C. Gracia: De 71 años de edad se dedica a la compra de hilos para la elaboracion de servilletas
Lucia J. A.: De 49 años de edad se dedica a la compra de hilos para la elaboracion de servilletas
Balvina Bartola A. L.: De 55 años de edad se dedica a la compra de hilos para la elaboracion de servilletas
Valeria Paula X: De 73 años de edad se dedica a la compra de hilos para la elaboracion de servilletas
texts.en:
The "Santiaguito" group is named this because the community in which they live has the same name: Santiago Jicayan, which is in the municipal of San Pedro Jicayan. This group is made up of 10 humble women with good intentions. All of them are neighbors in this area. They all work in trade, most embroider napkins and Nahua (dresses), and are hardworking and responsible women.

The representative of this group is Lucia J. A., 49 years old and married to Marcelino Garcia López who is a police officer. They have 8 children, 6 of which live with them. Lucia studied only through primary school. 

Lucia is requesting a loan to buy thread to make napkins. She uses the following: white linen, silk thread, cord, etc. In addition to embroidery she also sells chicken, so with the remainder of the loan she will buy chickens. 

Lucia has been in this business for 10 years and has learned to make the products from taking a course. She doesn't have a central spot where she sells the napkins, but she brings them to the surrounding communities to sell. Her products are different sizes and vary in price according to the type of thread she uses and the size. She sells products for any where from 20 pesos to 200 pesos. 

Previously she belonged to a group called "Sangre India" where together with other women they made the fabric of the napkins and had a person who collected and sold their products nationally, but as time went by the group broke up and now everyone sells their own products.

With the income she receives from sales, Lucia invests in a musical group called "Santiago" in which her youngest son plays the drums.

Her greatest dream is for her work to be recognized worldwide, that people from abroad will to buy her products, and with great effort and dedication she can achieve this. 

She feels very happy to receive this loan and thanks the foundation for providing people like her with loans.

The women that make up this group are the following:

Andrea M. A.: 59 years old and sells Regional Snacks.
Carmen V. L.: 41 years old and works making pastries.
Cenorina L. X: 40 years old and buys thread to make napkins.
Guadalupe J. X: 41 years old and sells Regional Snacks.
Victoria J. L.: 39 years old and purchases chicken for selling.
Brigida J. A.: 32 years old and works in pottery.
Florentina C. Gracia: 71 years old and buys thread to make napkins.
Lucia J. A.: 49 years old and buys thread to make napkins.
Balvina Bartola A. L.: 55 years old and buys thread to make napkins.
Valeria Paula X: 73 years old and buys thread to make napkins.

loans.use:
COMPRA DE HILOS PARA BORDAR

Purchase thread for embroidery

loans.name: Jennifer Nantoyie Ene

texts.en:
Jennifer has practiced livestock farming in Naivasha town for the last three years.  She is 22 years old, married to William Paronte, and they have two children.

She was introduced to KADET LTD by other clients and this will be her first loan.  She plans to use the loan amount to buy 10 goats and 10 sheep which she will sell later at a profit.

In future, Jennifer hopes to grow in the livestock business and be able to buy a piece of land and build a family home.

loans.use: To buy 10 goats and 10 sheep which she will sell later at a profit.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy a newer and bigger store

loans.name: Nilda

texts.en:
Mrs. Nilda V. is 42 years old and lives in Burgos, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She is blessed with three children. Her husband is a farmer and they own a little parcel of land. Although it is her husband who cultivates this land, gardening has also become her own primary activity. It began as a back-yard gardening project and eventually led to selling a few of her garden vegetables during market day. 

She’s thankful to Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative for providing them with financial assistance in the past. She is now applying for PHP 14,000 to buy farm pesticides and fertilizers for her garden. She also wants to buy a cow. 

She has many plans for the future. One of her dreams is that someday, she will be the one supplying vegetables in the market.

About PMPC: 

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy farm pesticides and fertilizers

loans.name: Sumaira's Group

texts.en:
Sumaira sells clothes to share the financial burden with her husband. She receives orders from her neighborhood clients and fulfills them by purchasing clothes in bulk from the clothes market named "Ichra" and "Azam market" in Lahore. She lives in Green town, which is a housing colony in Lahore. Lahore is Pakistan’s second largest city, known for its history and culture. Her house is made up of bricks and contains four rooms. She has been living here with her family for the past 12 years.
 
She is a 32-year-old lady who has four sons. Three of her sons are enrolled in a nearby school and getting their education. Her husband’s name is P. I. and he has a sound system business. He offers his services at different parties, musical shows and marriage ceremonies. 

Sumaira has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for further improvement of her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy the latest sound system that will help him provide better quality services to his clients and earn more profits. He has been operating this business for the past 10 years and Sumaira hopes that the loan investment will put a positive impact on her husband’s business and increase his profits. 
She is a new loan applicant of Asasah.

loans.use: To buy the latest sound system

loans.name: Zita

texts.en:
Zita S. is from the village of Sta. Ana, Talisayan, Misamis Oriental. She is 56 years old. Zita is married and has six adult children. To make a living, Zita owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods, and toothpaste in the local community. Zita has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Zita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Zita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Zita is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods and snack foods. This loan will be Zita's fourth loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Men

texts.en: Men T. D. is 45 years old and has two children who work. A farmer, she grows rice, onions, and potatoes in a field of 4500 square meters. She  uses these agricultural products to feed her family and to sell in a market in order to generate income. She has been a client since 2004, and she is always a good group leader. This year, she wants to expand her business by growing additional kinds of vegetables. She is requesting a loan of 9,810,000 VND to buy seed, fertilizer, and pesticide in order to increase her crop productivity.

loans.use: To buy seed, fertilizer, and pesticide

loans.name: Metodia

texts.en:
Metodia C. is from the town of Tagbilaran. She is 61 years old. To make a living, Metodia owns and operates a tailoring business. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing general alteration and tailoring services to local community members. Metodia also runs a small sari-sari (variety) store located at the front of her house.

Metodia joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Metodia has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Metodia is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fabrics and materials. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

loans.name: Tu

texts.en: Tu T. N. is a 35-year-old woman with 2 children. She is living in Mach trang village. Tu is a successful business woman who sells baby pigs. Every day, she goes to markets to buy baby pigs at a lower price and then sells them to farmers who have mother pigs with a few baby pigs. She has run this kind of business for 5 years and it gives her a good revenue that covers her family's spending. A client of Seda since 2004, she has been in good re-payment status. Currently, she wants a loan of 7630000 VND to invest in the business.

loans.use: To invest in the business.

loans.name: Glen

texts.en:
Glen P. is from the village of Sta. Cruz, Magsaysay, Misamis Oriental. He is 40 years old. Glen is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Glen owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector. He operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from the buying and selling of coconuts in the local community. Glen has been engaged in his business for over 5 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Glen joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Glen has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and working capital. Glen is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional coconuts to buy and sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Glen from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Phan's Group

texts.en:
There are four people who form a group loan. They are located in Lekh Pir village in Kandal province. 

Mrs. Phan K. is a 34 year-old married woman and she is the group leader. She was selected to be the group leader by the four members. She and her husband, Mr. Cheng Thol, earn their living by making doors and windows which they sell to support the family.  In order to support this business, Mrs. Phan K. would like to ask for a loan to buy more raw materials for her current business.   

This couple has four children: two are chefs in restaurants and the others are students in the local school.

loans.use: To buy raw materials.

loans.name: Josil

texts.en:
Josil M. has a "sari-sari" (variety store) in order to generate her daily income. She is 48 years-old and married.  She lives in Dolipos Alto, Oroquieta, Misamis Occidental. She has seven children. Out of seven, three of her children are still in school. Josil worked hard to make her family live comfortably. 

Josil joined Kiva partner Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative due to her desire to access funds for her "sari-sari" store business. Today, she is applying for a loan of 5,000 PHP. The money will be used to provide additional capital for her store. She hopes to replace her present "sari-sari" store with a concrete one and she plans to save for the education of her children.

loans.use: To provide additional capital.

loans.name: Van

texts.en: Van T. K. is 33 years-old. She is living with her family in Coloa Commune. Her main activity to earn a daily income is raising chickens and selling  eggs at a local market. This  activity has created a stable income and helps her provide good education for her two  children who are in Secondary school.  She has been a member of the Seda credit program since 2004 and she  has been a good client. Currently, to  expand her business, she wants to borrow 8502000 VND in order to build  a new house for her chickens.

loans.use: To build a new chicken house.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Lucy Ariri

texts.en:
Lucy Ariri is a Kenyan entrepreneur from the county of Kisumu, a city along the shores of Lake Victoria. She is married to Samwel Onyango who works in a motor repair workshop (garage). They have two children aged eight and 10 years and they live in the populous Nyamasaria Estate in Kisumu.

Lucy operates a salon and clothing material business within the same premises and has been doing this for the four years with success since she makes a monthly income of Kshs 10,000. She is taking out her second loan from KADET LTD  which she will use to buy two blow dryers for the salon, lining and school uniform material which are in high demand at this time, when schools have re-opened for the new semester.

She will use the anticipated profits to expand her business further by stocking what her clientele demands. Her dream is to one day open a big salon and boutique in Kisumu city.

loans.use: To purchase two blow dryers for the salon plus lining and school uniform materials

loans.name: Pheap's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of four people who are located in Preaek Hour Kaeut village in Kandal province. 

Mrs. Pheap S. was born in 1988 and is a married woman. She is the group leader. She was selected as the group leader by the other members. She is a grocery seller in the local village. Since her business is doing well, she would like to ask for a loan to buy more groceries to enlarge her business. Her husband, Mr. Sum Chanthou, is a truck driver who owns a truck to transport soil. With their careers, they are able to earn some income to support their family. 

This couple has a child who is only three years old.

loans.use: To buy more groceries.

loans.name: Phuong

texts.en: Phuong T. D.  is 36 years-old with four children who are in Secondary school and Kindergarten. Being a farmer, she focuses on growing rice and vegetables  to meet the family food demand. In addition, she raises 300 chickens for their eggs in order to earn a daily income. Ms D.  has borrowed  from the Seda credit program seven times previously and invested successfully in farming.  Currrently,she wants a loan of 8,502,000 VND in order to buy food for chickens.

loans.use: To buy food for chickens.

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Delia O. is from the village of Bacnor West. She is 40 years old and married with a school-aged child. To make a living, Delia owns and operates a business that provides manicures and pedicures in her local community. Delia has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month.

Delia joined ASKI in 2010 to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI that was used to purchase materials and expand her services. Delia is requesting a loan of 6,000 PHP to purchase business materials. This will be her third loan. Delia plans to use the additional revenue generated with her loan to pay her child’s school tuition fees. 


About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Luu

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Mrs. Rosalinda D., 63 years old, is married and has 4 children. She lives in Maular, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. After hearing some news about Paglaum Muti-Purpose Cooperative, she became interested in it and she then joined the coop. She has availed herself of loans and started her pig raising project. 

Mrs. Rosalinda D. is applying for a 5,000 PHP loan to buy feed and vaccines for her pigs. She dreams of building a decent home for her family. She also hopes that someday her business will become successful and more profitable.

loans.use: to buy feed and vaccines

loans.name: Arlene

Arlene P. is from the village of Santiago, Gingoog City. She is 37 years old, married and has 6 school-aged children. Arlene owns and operates a specialized retail store, buying and selling fish such as milk fish, sardines and mackerel, in the local community. Arlene has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2010, Arlene joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Arlene has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to to purchase additional inventory and increase working capital. Arlene is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish such as sardines and salmon. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Arlene from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

loans.use: to purchase additional fish

loans.name: Luong

texts.en:
Luong T. T. is 39 years old and has two children who are in high school. She is a farmer who grows rice and is raising ten pigs to sell for meat. Every three months, merchants come to her house to buy her pigs and Luong can make 5,000,000 VND from her work as a pig seller.

Luong joined SEDA’s credit program over four years ago and has a good attitude about repayment. She is requesting a loan of 7,194,000 VND to buy fertilizer and food for her pigs.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pig food

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en:
Mrs. Lilian L. is 60 years old, married and has six children. She lives in Mitazan, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. With a desire to help her husband, she ventured into bread-making and snack sales, starting up with capital of only PHP 1,000. Her primary customers are her neighbors, friends and co-members of Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative. 

Mrs. Lilian L. joined the co-op in order to avail herself of their credit facilities. She was thankful to Paglaum MPC that her purpose of obtaining additional capital was realized. She is now applying for a loan of PHP 8,000 to buy ingredients for snack and viand sales.  She dreams of owning a parcel of land someday.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients for snack and viand sales

loans.name: Joseph Muiruri

texts.en: Joseph has practiced farming in Naivasha since 2001.  He is 39 years old, married to Eunice Wanja and they have one child. Joseph was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his third loan.  He has repaid all his previous loans well and in good time.  Joseph plans to use the loan amount to buy potato seeds, fertilizer and pesticides. In the future, Joseph hopes to have his own farming equipment and machinery.

loans.use: to buy potato seeds, fertilizer and pesticides

loans.name: Dioscora

texts.en:
Mrs. Dioscora G., 59 years old, is widowed and lives in Dolipos Alto, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental. She strives hard to make a living. It is not easy for her to be alone without a partner, but life must go on with Dioscora. She was blessed with four children, who are now adults.

Dioscora's primary source of income comes from her sari-sari (general) store. She has been a member of Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative since 2009 and has already had two loans. Dioscora says she is thankful for the cooperative because of the financial assistance given to her family. She has applied for a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy additional goods for her sari-sari business. She hopes for a bountiful life ahead. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy additional goods

loans.name: Charito

texts.en:
Charito B. is from the town of Tagbilaran. She is 39 years old and married with 5 children, aged 18, 16, 13, 11 and 5. Charito is a Natasha (a direct sales company) dealer. She says she started selling Natasha products, such as shirts and shoes, to her friends. She also sells dried fish in her community. Charito is working hard to build her business. She also plans to sell Pyrex kitchen cookware.

Charito joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Charito is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ana Theresa

texts.en:
Ana Theresa B. is from the village of Eastern, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 41 years old. She is married and has 3 school-aged children. 

To make a living, Ana Theresa owns & operates a mini-restaurant. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from serving a variety of different meals to customers in the local community, like pork adobo & afritada. She has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Ana Theresa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase food & drinks for the restaurant. 

Ana Theresa is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients like pork, vegetables & spices. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Ana Theresa from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients for restaurant

M. borrowed a loan to stock more charcoal to resell. In the future, with the extra profits from  her business she hopes to build a house to rent out.

loans.use: To stock more charcoal to sell

loans.name: Marilou

To make a living, Marilou owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods, mineral water, salt by the pack & toothpaste, to the local community. Marilou has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 7500 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Marilou joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marilou has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & fund working capital. 

Marilou is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell, like shampoo and soaps. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Marilou from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Tatyana

texts.en:
Tatyana is married and has a grown son and a daughter. She lives in Zaporozhye.  Tatyana sells office supplies, dishware and umbrellas in the local market called ‘Yubileinyi’. She owns three vending locations in the same marketplace.  She launched her enterprise thirteen years ago. Currently, Tatyana has over 80,000 UAH in inventory. Her gross income is approximately 24,000 UAH a month. 

Tatyana is seeking a loan of 15,000 UAH to increase her turnover capital and purchase assorted merchandise. In particular, she is planning to buy dishware for further retail sale in her kiosks. Tatyana decided to work in this sphere of trade because there is less competition, and this type of merchandise always sells well.

loans.use: To buy dishware to sell

While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling cosmetics and beauty products from NATASHA & AVON  in the local community. Honey Fe has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month from these activities.

Honey Fe is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell, such as cosmetics & colognes. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Honey Fe from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

loans.name: Agripina

texts.en:
Agripina M. is from the village of Bacnor West. She is 36 years old. Agripina is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Agripina owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for breeding. Agripina has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Agripina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Agripina is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Agripina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Vith

texts.en: Mrs. Vith K. is a married woman who lives in Thommeakney village, Takeo province. She was born in 1982. She is a farmer who owns a half-hectare plot of land where she grows rice to sell to support her family and she is a pig breeder, too. The rice field has infertile soil and it has a lot of insects. So to improve rice production, Mrs. Vith K. is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticide. With any remainder of the loan she is going to buy more piglets and pig feed. She is a mother of four children, three of whom are studying in a local public school, but the youngest one is a 3-year-old. Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide

Hannah plans to use the loan amount to buy a dairy cow. In the future, Hannah hopes to develop her dairy business and be able to supply milk in large quantities.

texts.en: Mrs. Srey Mai S. is a widow with one child who is enrolled in local public school. She is living in a four-member household in Tadak Pong village, Takeo province, and she was born in 1977. She is a farmer who owns a 1-hectare plot of land where she cultivates rice to sell to support her family. Presently, she wants to buy a new motorbike to use, yet her savings are not sufficient to do so. So Mrs. Srey Mai S. is asking for a loan to buy a new motorbike.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike

loans.name: Dixon Odera

texts.en:
Dixon O. is a hardworking 43-year-old man from the lakeside city of Kisumu, situated along the fresh water Lake Victoria, in Western Kenya. He is married to Pamela Akinyi, a professional teacher in Kisumu, and the couple has two children, 4 and 10 years old.

Dixon has been a welder at Mamboleo, a populous and upcoming estate in the city of Kisumu, for the last six years. He makes a monthly income of KES 20,000, which he reinvests in the business and uses to provide for his family's basic needs. Dixon is taking out a second loan from KADET LTD, which he will use to buy metal bars for his welding work. Dixon will use the anticipated profits for savings, to buy more inventory and to feed his family. His dream is to open a permanent welding workshop as opposed to the current open air workshop which is not weather-friendly. The workshop will also act as a store for his products.

loans.use: to buy metal bars for welding

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose O. is 40 years old, married, and has three school-aged children.  She is currently selling cold drinks such as water and fruit juices made from mango, orange, pineapple, guava, etc. Rose requested a loan to stock more cold drinks to sell. Rose hopes to build a house in the future with extra profits from her business.

loans.use: To stock more cold drinks to sell

She plans to use additional income to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines.
